text: Bottle at Side Project Cellar. 375 mL bottle shared by George. Thanks dude. The pour a darker brown with a light khaki head and a few spots of lace. The aroma is interesting. Lots of dark fruits and a strong Belgian yeast. Its a little cardboardy, but not too shabby. The flavor is much of the same. Dark fruits, heavy malts, and a light sweetness. Not too bad. The mouth feel is a little heavy with a soft carbonation and a lingeringly sweet and fruity yeast finish.

Dark brown I color. Bold spicy and fruity flavors with nice complexity. Big 9.5% alcohol

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep copper, approaching brown with sudsy off white head and nice lacing. Roasty malty aroma, sweet. Sweet malty with light dry fruit and spiced notes. 

Notes: on tap at the brew pub, June 17
Bottle date: 11/26/16. Dark fruit (dates/figs), caramel notes, I get a hint of cigarette ash? on the finish, slight bitterness. Quite a bit of particulates when first poured. Not boozy at all for 9%.

From tap at the brewery. Copper brown color with light beige head. Malty, hoppy and yeasty aroma, caramel, bread, spicy, some fruity notes. Heavy sweet, light acidic and light bitter taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

2014 bottle in 2017. Pours deep red brown, beige head. Aroma is raisin, banana, caramel malts, dates, prune, chocolate. Flavor is sweet dark fruits, caramel, milk chocolate, banana, light spice, buttered bread. Full bodied super smooth sweet Belgian, great display of the style.

Pours black with a low off white head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, sour notes, brown sugar, roasted nuts. Taste is fruity with farmhouse notes and light chocolate notes. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation and quite dry.
Draft at the source. Clear amber, light beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, spice and yeast. Taste is dark fruit, dark chocolate, coffee notes, raisins, spice, yeast. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2017 Draft at Bru Craft. Translucent very dark brown/black pour. Soft light brown foam. Nice lace. Somehow both giant and light. Complex black liquorice caramels. Dark chocolate sugar candies. French roast coffee. Molasses. Oak. Nutmeg. Peat. Vague pecan pie. Strange complex Belgian dark brew. Burnt celeriac. Very unusual. A must try!
Appearance: clear dark amber with thin white head; Taste: belgian spice, a little roasty; malty and sweet but not really complex; Overall: a little disappointing.

Taster pour at the brewery. Clear brown pour with a nice fluffy white head and lacing. Rasin and malt in the nose. Nice classic dark Belgian taste. Slightly estery. Really nice finish, just a hint of malt and dark fruits. This would be fun in a bourbon barrel.
Im not even reviewing this properly. Banana faint clove. Not good. Certainly not worthy of its overall rating. Disappointing.

Draught at Russian River. Dark brown color, beige head. Bittersweet taste with citrus, yeast, banana, nuts, ripe fruits, plum, a bit of chocolate and wheat. Bittersweet finish with citrus, plum, banana, wheat, yeast and a bit of chocolate. Very nice brew.
Bottle batch 101014. Pours a dark brown. Light carbonation. Rich coco and classic dark Belgian aroma. Smooth oh so smooth. Rich flavor with a spicy finish somewhat that masks a warming.

375ml bottle at Brians (thx, Brian!). Bottled on 10/10/14. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma and taste are fruity, caramel, sugary, spices, Belgian yeasts. Very good brewed beer, fits with the original style by 100%.

12.7oz bottle, Oct 2014 vintage. (Lost track of where I got this because I was at the brewery before this was bottled) Color is a very deep brown. Still great carbonation, laces the side of the chalice. Aroma is light oak, chocolate, brown sugar, and of course dark fruit. 
Taste is dark breads, with cherries, wood, very light spice, and a decent showing of Belgian yeast. Initially sweet followed by a light boozy finish. Medium to lighter in body. Smooth texture with soft carbonation. All in all, my only complaint is the lighter body. That said this held up well and is still very tasty.
August 3, 2016 - on tap at RRBC. Clear brown pour with some head and minimal lacing. Aroma and taste had dark fruit, chocolate, spice and belgian yeast.

On tap at Russian River Brewing in Santa Rosa, CA-USA. Dark Amber clear color, ivory cap. Nose is spicy sweet, caramel a bit. Mouth: sour cherry, sour funky mild notes in clean and red-fruits driven drink.

Draught @ Russian River Brewing, Santa Rosa, California (20.04.2016)   

Strong Dark Ale, 9% alk. 19 BLG  

Bardzo złożny smak i aromat. Głównie przyprawy, zboża, przypieczona skórka chlebowa. W oddali gęsta czekolada. Czuć belgijski charakter. Mocno owocowy trunek (ciemne owoce), belgijskie drożdże, pomarańcze, brzoskwinie, morele. W kolejnych łykach akcenty bananów i lekkie cytrusy. Mnóstwo przypraw w kontrze do owoców. Czekoladowe i żywiczne akcenty świetnie zbalansowane z długim, pozostajacym w ustach, ale przyjemnym średnio-wytrawnym finiszem. Średnie ciało. Ciekawe piwo.

A: Brown, big tan head, tan foam, minimal lacing
A: fruity, alcohol is the dominant smell
T: low bitterrness with sweetness that last long
MF: balance
OA: Excellent beer for the style, ok to repeat, look for
Drank: April 14, 2016
Batch no 7, 1pt bottle at home. Tiny head, caramel and dark rasin in color and aroma. Taste of dark malt, fruits and some complex notes i cant place. It might by slightly to old but still delicious.
@ Russian River 16-3-7: Typisk belgisk med toner av nötter, kola, jäst och kryddor. Nja ...
On tap at RR. Poured clear brown with white head. Aroma minimal malty sweet. Light carb med bod. Taste sweet brown ale nutty light yeast banana.

Draft sample at the brewpub, Santa Rosa. Clear reddy amber coloured pour with lasting light beige head. Aroma is brown sugars, little spice red fruit, dried fruit. Little fruit cake on the nose as well. Flavor is composed of full and rich fruit cake, some toffee, raisin. Smooth, warming alcohol. Palate is semi sweet. Full bodied. Warming alcohol
 Frothy carbonation. Good quad.

On tap at Toronado. Deep copper pour with thin white head. Aroma is rich nutty, malty, light caramel. Taste is toasty, rich malty sweet flavors, light brown sugar, light peppermint. Palate is med full bodied with good carbonation.

Draught at Toronado SF. Almost clear deep brown liquid with small to medium off-white head. Aroma of dried fruit, light banana, raw sugar, raisins, bread and toast. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of dried fruit, raw sugar and raisins. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice.
Draft at Toronado. Nose is huge in candied figs and dried fruit. Amazing. Deep red pour. Taste is a wonderful combo of dried fruit as well. Moderately dry finish. Really good.
Draft - Sweet plum and dark raisin. Deep brown with a decent beige head. Roasty notes, seem plum and prune. More dark and roasty than fruity.
Tap at russian river, santa rosa. Dark reddish brown color, white head. Aroma has sweet caramel notes, some roasty, vanilla. Taste has chocolate, some coffee, hint of vanilla.
Pours a deep reddish brown on tap with fluffy tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma and taste of dark fruit and dark malty Belgian esters. Booze is incredibly well hidden, clean and wonderful.
Tap poured cola brown with a beige head and nice lacing. Aromas of raisins, dark fruit, caramel malt, and chocolate. Very smooth. Yum.

Refrigerated small format brown bottle, bottled on October 10, 2014, corked at capped poured into a Trappist glass. Clear dark brown with reddish hues and small beige head. Aroma is fruity dark malt, medium body, lower carbonation, and some small bubble lacing. Taste is dark malt and some dark fruit (mostly raisins).

375ml bottle thanks to ditmier. Pours out a dark amber topped with a small head. Nose is pit fruit toffee wood plum spice and some belg yeast. Taste is more of the pit fruit sweetness wood and a nice spice. I have enjoyed this one plenty of times and it never lets down.

Dark brown pour with slight garnet tint. Creamy foam tan head that lasted a while. Aroma of prune and raisins. Taste malty sweet and caramel along with the plum and raisin character from the obvious aromas. Sweet and dry finish. Great brew.
Une bouteille 10/10/14. Un liquide brun claire. Un nez de chocolat, de raisins secs et de bois. Touche de levure spéciale. Une bouche ronde de chocolat piquant et boisée. Un classique.

375ml bottle enjoyed @ home. Pour dark deep amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is caramel, plums, raisins, dates, vanilla and brown sugar. Flavour is not as sweet as the aroma suggests. Full bodied, slick texture, soft carbonation. Finish is long, medium sweet with dark dried fruits.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits - Castro, San Francisco - CA. Color: clear deep brown beer with no carbonation and small white/ivory foam. Smell: malt domination, sweet caramel and notes of grape fruits and red fruits. Taste: good malt taste, sweet and red fruits. Notes of red fruit as grapes and raspberry. Good finish. Really drinkable and amazing beer. Aftertaste: caramel and notes of malt. Fruity and sweet. Amazing beer !

(37.5 cl. Bottled on : 10/10/14) Belle robe rougeâtre ou brunâtre, cest selon. Tête mousseuse crémeuse qui accompagne la dégustation. Arômes de mélasse, de raisins, de chocolat, dépices, de prunes, doranges. Profil vineux très intéressant. Que cest agréable de renouer avec ce style! Mes papilles ne sont pas déçues. La richesse des arômes se reflète dans les saveurs. Tout y est pour le plaisir : fruits, malts, levures, alcool doux. En bouche, le corps de moyenne densité est surexcité par les bulles. Je peux cependant dire que cette action nenlève rien au plaisir de la dégustation. Mon palais est bien nettoyé et cest tant mieux. La finale est assez longue, modérément sèche, maltée et fruitée mais aussi piquante par le jeu de ses levures. Ça fait du bien de boire une bonne Belge.

Dark brown-blackish color with thin foam layer. Light fruity smell (dates). The taste is sweet, and fruity (dates & prunes) with decent chocolate notes, hints of licorice with a foamy carbonation and a dry and calm aftertaste.
Bottle at SinH4s Goodbye Event. Malt nose, almost a bit roasty. Strong and sweet yet not too much, some matching booziness. To the point, but not exciting.
Fruity, resinous, a bit sugary, some dark malts, plums, port, sweet cocoa, coconut. Good complexity, rich taste, quite delicate. Great balance.
375ml bottle pours a dark reddish brown with a thin off white head. caramel dark fruit and raisin taste

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2015 I was just looking up my review of this beer only to find I hadnt entered it yet. No idea how long ago it was when I has this, but thankfully I took detailed notes (which follow): 375 ml bottle from APEX. The last of the widely-distributed "ations" for me. 
 
Appearance: Pours with minimal head, the tiniest hint of a few bubbles but otherwise still. Beautiful deep, dark, ruby brown, clear. 4.5
 
Aroma: Beautiful raisins, plums simmering in brown sugar. Vanilla, port. Smells like a rich, decadent, boozy plum pie-like dessert. From the aroma, this is one I would definitely love to sip slowly like a fortified dessert wine. 9
 
Taste: Not nearly as sweet as the nose would suggest. Plenty sweet, sure, with loads of lush dark fruits. Id say raisin, but raisins remind me of a fruit thats over the hill, whereas this is in its prime. Somewhat dry finish. 8.5
 
Palate: Full body, slick, oily texture. Very soft carbonation -- not quite flat, but close. Still awfully fucking nice, though. 3
 
Overall: RR never disappoints. Never. Like Hemmingway. I sat in a lecture once with my Professor, in which he demonstrated that the boy in the Old Man and the Sea is an adult in his mid twenties, which both changes nothing and everything about the way it reads. Russian River creations are like that. The complexity lies hidden beneath the seeming simplicity. A beer you can enjoy without thinking about, but which rewards you for thinking about it. I expect I could return to this after decades of beer nerd-dom and still marvel how how they do what they do. [8.5/4.5/9/3/16=4.1]
 
Revisited 7/22/15, and dont find the magic I did last time. Wouldnt be inspired to spout Hemmingway at any rate. Body is a bit thin, flavors one-dimensional. Maybe it hurts that I was just typing up my Westy 12 review, but whatever it is Id call this a 3.8 at best this time around. Adjusting down slightly.
Reddish brown slight haze off white head. Aroma is 50/50 blend of malts and wonderful yeasty character. Taste powerful malt some candi sugar and silky smooth mouthfeel.
Bottle from a trade. Many thanks! Dark brown, beige foam. Medium carbonation. Sweet and fruity with notes of caramel and brown sugar. Good and well balanced.

3 oz chilled pour from tap into cylindrical taster as part of Russian Rivers everything on tap sampled (16 beers this time around) at the brewery itself. I realize that drinking 16 different 3 oz pours is not ideal for proper rating, but when will I ever have an opportunity like this again?

Caramel color, fairly translucent.

375 mL bottle, corked, poured. Bottled on 10/10/14. Pours dark with a high active fizz head. Malt forward aroma with some dark fruit. Dusty dry raisin flavor with a slight toasty finish. Late spice comes through, and a little oaky. Fun beer to try. I think I missed the appropriate season though. Still an awesome beer.

Bottle pour split, thanks Andrew for sharing this one. Always love having some Russian River. Very dark brown pour, thin head. 10-10-14 batch/Bottle date. Kind of coffee and caramel aroma for me, bitter hop taste, dark roast, very nice beer here.

Tap at brewery with commonmac and rosskyle and wildcard. Nearly black with foamy white head. Subtle sweet roast aroma. Dark fruit, some funk, sweet and roasted malty. Very smooth. Tastes better ad it slightly warms. The full body is amazing. Great texture. Terrific.

Tap at the brewery with commonshawn, rosskyle, and wildcard. Goblet. Dark copper almost brown in color. Tannish head. Roasted malts on the nose with spice and dark fruit. Taste is quite nearly perfect with a moments of dark plum and raisins, bitterness, funky yeast, and sugars. All blending to produce an amazingly satisfying drinking experience. Mouthfeel is super soft and smooth. I want more of this almost immediately after the sip finishes. Outstanding.

Served on tap at Russian River. Dark black color with medium off white head. Aroma of plum, raisin, and alcohol. Heavy body carbonated mouth feel. Flavor is plum and spice.

Draught at the Russian River Brewing Co, Santa Rosa, CA.
Clear dark copper colour with a small to mid-size off-white head. 
Raisins, sweet dark fruits and mild spices in the aroma. The amount of raisins and dark fruits in the aroma is reasonable. Thats very nice. Dark fruits, mild bitterness and malt in the flavour.
Spicy breads yeast smell. Flavor of brown sugar and complex malts. Finishes spicy Belgian yeast with nice alcohol warmth.

Might be released in January but a really good dude just brought this over.
He had a growler of this. 
I poured my portion into a tulip.
The appearance was a semi-hazy to dark brown color with a slim fingers worth of white foamy head that dissipated within about a light minute. Light lacing. 
The smell had a tender sweet spice rolling over top of a light dark fruity blend of sweet caramel malts. Dosed with a nice apple aroma, subtly everything combines nicely. 
The taste was moderately sweet and spicy leading to a nice underscore of bitterness strolling about. Theres no aftertaste but did have a nice sticky Belgian spice finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation seemed smooth and carried an acceptable harshness about it.
Overall, I say this was an absolutely amazing Belgian Strong dark ale that I would have again.

From bottle bought at the brewery to glass. Deep reddish-brown with tan head. Moderate low deep fruit with restrained alcohol. Lakes the depth of this style, and Vinnies other brews. But still quite good.
On tap. Belgian. Bitter citrus, grapefruit. Odd Chinese buffet character as it warms. Smells a little like sweat. Thick, sweet.

Pours a solid black with a foamy tan head and lacing. It has a nice aroma of biscuit, some toast, and dark fruit. The flavor is dark fruit and spices up front and a slightly spicy and bready finish over a medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12.7oz bottle, huge thanks to aabean. Bottled 10/10/14. Labeled 9.5%. Totally hazy dark red brown color. Thin khaki bubbly head. Just a few short ropes of lace, but its a pretty nice color. Awesome oak, dark fruit, mild spice, chocolate. Toasty malt, some vanilla. Raisin. Super-complex and tasty. I had high hopes, but this is better than I imagined. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Lightly slick body, slightly dry finish. Perfect texture for a belgian. Moderate sweet taste, nice light to moderate bitter balance. Sweet isnt lingering. Good long steady aftertaste pushing the awesome aroma forward. Absolutely fantastic belgian dark strong ale. Even better than expected. One of the best Ive ever had.
Pretty hazelnut color, sticky lacing. Aroma is cherries, dark fruits, raisins. Flavor is Belgian spices, dark fruits, malty and a bit of chocolate. Good.
Bottle. Beautiful chestnut brown pour, topped with a bubbly tan head. Nose is floral, a little malty and toasty. Clean floral taste, nuts, toast, and yeast. Light spice.

Draft @ City Beer Store on 1/19/15. Pours a dark brown/burgundy with minimal tan head. Aroma of malty, raisin sweetness with some banana, cola nut and spice. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and creamy. Palate of dark fruit, malty sweet, cola and spice. Well balanced dark belgian with great aroma and flavor.

Bottle from C-mini mart in Dublin, CA. Pours reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of Sweet caramel, malt, faint booze. Taste of sweet malt, raisins. The alcohol is very well hidden. Mouth feel is a bit thin, maybe I just expected it to be thicker because of the appearance. Nice fine carbonation.

Bottle, courtesy of a kind soul... shared in a location remote of my dining room.
Pours a very dark brown with with reddish hues where the light hits, its got a great head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.

The aroma is nutty and rich with some leaf rot. Its got some light chocolate, its aromatic, inviting and rich. 

The flavor is nutty with some light leafiness. Its rich with some fruitiness while remaining only lightly sweet with a dry-ish finish. The bitterness & spicy notes are mild but well employed for balance.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a moderate pillowy brown head on there. Nose has a lot of raisin coming through for me with a bit of caramel and spice as well. Taste is fairly sweet with the raisin really being salient on this.

Dark brown in color... Aroma of overripe bananas, spices, nutty malts, raisins... Flavor of nutty malts, spices, yeast, tobacco... Solid beer

"quite good - i think this is the better half of the RR/Avery Collaberation, but funny enough, neither beer is as good as the combo. this one has banana and spices, with other dark fruits and a heavier body as well. A very quaffable ale!"

Bottle thanks to Nielsen ! Pours a dull raw umber color with three fingers of khaki suds. Lots of sweet banana bread undertones, earthy spice, kola nut, candied anise, nutty bitterness, date, raisin, soft burnt sugar. Really well restrained yet packs a punch of flavors from beginning to end.

Taste is medium bodied, nice bready dark fruit, nutty cola, red grape notes, plum. Finish has nice mild creaminess with earthy dark fruits, touches of cola sweetness, and dark multi grain bread.
(backlog) Draft at hulmeville inn. Brown pour with tan head. Chocolate, tart fruit, some malt sweetness in flavor and aromas. Finish is smooth.

Bottle, Batch 010. Pours a cloudy brown with medium frothy tan head that lasts, lots of carb. The aroma is a strong yeast, raisins and spice Medium mouthfeel figs, sweet malt with nice spice with lingering dry finish. Good.
Deep brown pour. Complex aroma of raisins, dark fruits and yeast. Amazing. Flavor is raisins, dates, nuts, alcohol, and dark fruits. Wow.

Sample at Russian River, Santa Rosa, CA. The sample pour was brought to me with several other beers, and is a dark maroon with an uneven thin head and active carbonation. Aroma is dark fruits, malt and spices. Flavor is same, mild and not aggressive. Alcohol is well-masked. From notes 2/19/13.
Growler from the brewery. Pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Chocolate with mild sweetness and a bit of spice.

Pours a dark amber color with an off white head. Chocolate, spices, fruit hop and malt aroma. Fruit, spice, malt and chocolate flavors. Medium body and carbonation with a malt and slight alcohol finish.
I thought this tasted a bit like a plum brandy, somewhat Christmassy. Pretty nice, overall.

Tap at Avery, same recipe but brewed at Avery for the Collaboration not Litigation Ale. Pours hazy copper brown with fine khaki head. Settles quickly with thin lace. Aroma is fruity, huge belgian yeast, ester, big banana, quite sweet. Flavor is banana, sweet and cereal malt, apple, with a fruity, grain and caramelized malt finish. Banana fruitiness is very big and sweet. Soft carbonation and medium body. Would be curious to see how this compares to a batch brewed at RR.
On tap @ RR. Pour is hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavor are both sweet with notes of caramel malts, dried fruit, and booze. Bitter and yeasty finish.

On tap at the Brewpub in February 2014.

Clear amber with a small head. On the sweet side with light roasted malt, fruit, some licorice and some nuts. Well hidden alcohol and with a thick mouthfeel. Quite tasty.
Sampler at the brewery- pours clear dark copper with minimal head. Aroma is chocolate, some spices. Taste is similar.
From the sampler tray at the brewery. Nutty, roasty, toasted marshmallow in flavor and aroma.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a light brown deep amber color with a light tan head. Aroma is a spicy darker malt character. Flavor is moderately sweet and spicy. Clove lasts long into the finish. Fantastic.

Ruby brown pour with one finger of sandy tan head. Light tartness in the flavor, coffee notes, and very light roast. Hint of tartness and fruity notes. Light chocolate notes with a touch of sweetness.

Dark color with a smallish head dark sugars, light fruit and hint of funk. Mouthfeel a hint thin, Nice aged beer.

On draft. Dark brown with a thin off-white head. Sweet malt, raisins, some spice. Very good.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours amber with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, fruitiness and yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, nuts, grains and warming alcohol. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bold aroma. Dark amber color with thick lacy head. Full of flavor with a smooth finish. Can feel some alcohol.

The Belgian yeasty aroma was there bit with strong fruity esters. Dark brown with a quickly vanishing head. The beers from RR all seem to have a wine essence to them. Weighty palate that was smooth with decent carbonation. The taste matched the aroma with a burnt sugar aspect that was brief. Some hops presence for balance. More dark cooked fruits. Good offering.
Nice strong beer with a bitter finish. Im not sure what else to say but I need more characters so Im just going to keep rambling on a little bit.

Pours dark red with a tan head that dissipates quickly. Nose is sweet toffee, caramel, Belgian ale spice, a backbone of malt. Taste is much the same with bold malt, prune, and raisin. Tasty, full bodied brew. Very nice!

Aromas of dark malts, peat, molasses, earth 
Taste... Ooooh the taste... L;oaded with sweet caramel malts, molasses, barnyard, honey fudge,

Pours reddish brown, slightly hazy, with low tan head. Aroma of brown sugar dark fruit, barnyard, yeast, spices, some bread. Taste is boozy with cherries, port wood. Initially sweet followed by a light alcohol bitterness. Long, boozy finish. Medium to full creamy body with soft carbonation.
Had on draft at the brewery. Warming, fruity alcohol, malty, a bit hot for me. The alcohol heat really killed the enjoyment of this beer.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2013 Drank on tap at wholefoods tap room beer dinner. A: rich chocolate covered banana, fig, dark caramel. Slight pepper note, slight mineral note. A: dark mahogany, totally brite. Long lasting off white head. T: frozen chocolate covered banana. Hop spiciness, dark toffe, caramel, burnt toast, slight coffe, slight mineral note, slight clove flavor. P: good carbonation, slightly viscous. Dry but lingering chocolaty bitterness. O: great example of a strong dark. Dry and yeasty but balanced out by the alcohol and rich flavors. Just enough roastiness

Sample at the brewpub. Pours a dark mahogany brown color with a medium tan head that recedes slowly. Patchy lacing on the glass. The aroma consists of chocolate, raisins and malt. Medium to full body with flavors of chocolate malt, caramel, dark fruit and yeast. The finish is sweet with an earthy yeast and fruit aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

Batch 010
Aroma is balanced between light malt notes, moderate fruit esters and some medium light phenolics. Sweet raisin, toffee and treacle with fig, plum, carmelized sugar, clove and faint pepper. 
Pours brown to dark brown with some faint ruby highlights. Very big moderately thick tan head that slowly but steadily recedes until its about a quarter inch thick then it recedes very slowly. Moderately high lacing. 
Flavor is a bit more malt forward with some dark caramel, toffee, chocolate and light roast. Some raisin, cherry and plum esters in moderate amounts. Medium to medium light bitterness. Light clove note with some coriander as well. Some sweetness mid palate but the finish dries out a bit in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderately high carbonation. Low astringency and medium high alcohol heat. Belgian yeast tends to feel hot to me. 
Overall a fairly good beer, but definitely not the best from Russian River. It feel a bit too carbonated for me and the finish lacks some depth. Good ester complexity, but the rest seems a bit one dimensional. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark brown with light brown head. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, liquorice. Yeasty taste with some chocolate, dark fruit and some coffee.
Snifter pour. Thin a dark. Quickly dissipating head. Spicy smell, but overall pretty faint. Same for taste, also boozy. Goes down smooth though

On tap at RR. Dark amber brown pour with a thin, rapidly dissipating tan head. Aroma of caramel, plum, and roasted malt. Taste is thick, sweet, and characteristic of the style. Raisin, sugar, and a mildly bitter finish.
Taster at Brew pub, Pours dark copper with tan head. Spicy nose, toffee and caramel. Dried grap taste. Not bad, but not one of my favorites.

Shared a 375 in a couple of snifters.  Much darker than expected.  Some ruby highlights but otherwise as dark as night.  Huge cumulus clouds looking head.  Pillowy and brown.  Smooth texture with a little fizz bite.  Sweet, fruity and malty.  On par with many things I had in Belgium.  More please.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy weak woody aroma. Fruity malty spicy caramel flavor with weak yeasty hints. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty caramel finish.
Draft @ brewpub. Pours clear mahogany ruby with a smalk beige head. Aroma is fruity malty spicy a bit herbal and yeasty with some phenolic tones. Flavor similar, sweet fruity and medium bitter.

damn this was good...aged about a year, and I think that helped.  Pours plum colored with off white head.  Super super smooth, taste of dark fruit, fig, yeast.  Dry finish.  Way too drinkable for 9.5%

375ml bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a big tan head and good lacing. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, dried fruit, and spices. Taste is raisins, caramel, chocolate, malt, and some alcohol coming through.

Pours a slightly translucent mahogany with moderate carbonation apparent.  Nose is caramel, some dark fruit, and a metalic note.  Flavor is the same, without the metal, and with some sweet molasses notes.  Really good mouthfeel for a beer of this style.

Thanks, Santa! Kinda surprised that it took me so long to finally try this one from RR. And though Im generally not big on the heavy, strong dark ales these days, this one delivered mightily. Deep brown pour with amber hints, loads of carbonation. Strong sweet malts and ripe yeast in the nose, with a full range of fruits. While theres more banana and so forth in the aroma, theres a nice citrus component that keeps things balanced and quite flavorful, steering the beer well away from the heavy, chewy quality that often afflicts this style. Good stuff.

The epitome of a fine dark Belgian. Incredibly smooth and incredibly balanced. Fruit in the aroma and in the taste, with just the right hint of spice. ABV says 9, but it drinks like a session beer; not a whiff of astringency. Near-perfect!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at Ma Che, Roma, 09/02/13, sourced from Beermongers, PDX.
Lightly hazed chestnut brown with a thin off white head that clears to a film and the edge of the glass.
Nose is dark fruits, light yeast, spice, dates, orange.
Taste comprises dark malt, yeast, dates, farmy notes, brett tones, candied sugars.
Medium bodied with light spritzy carbonation, a little too much for my liking.
Overall a decent Belgian strong but at the lower end of the RR spectrum.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 09/02/2013 375ml bottle (thanks Theydon_Bois!). Bellissima color miele di castagno con riflessi mogano, schiuma beige un po stentata ma abbastanza persistente. Al naso è una goduria incredibile, prugne secche e datteri, vaniglia, caramello, zucchero di canna, un po di tostato e spezie. In bocca è complessa e dannatamente bilanciata, dolce, caramello, frutta matura, ancora spezie, il finale è amarognolo, pulito. Corpo medio, alcol non pervenuto, gran scorrevolezza, eleganza. Una birra sopraffina, sicuramente tra le migliori belgian strong ale mai bevute al di fuori del Belgio.

Pours a nice hazy dark amber color with a foamy off white head.  A nice sweet malt aroma with notes of chocolate and raisins.  Flavor is initially bittersweet malt with raisin notes although there is not much finish to it.  Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is average.  Overall a good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2014 In a trade from a very generous trader. Batch 11 printed on the corked and caged bottle. Poured 1/25/13. Dark brown with very little light coming through. Very very creamy kahki colored head. Aroma of raisins, cherries, and possibly a hint of smoke. Belgian yeast comes through and this gives of fruit qualities of a dubbel or quad. Some prickle up front from the carbonation and spice as a blast of fruit heads down your throat. Plums and berries all over. Very smooth. Finishes with a burst of unexpected chocolate and a lingering nuttiness. Chocolate really starts coming out with some more sips. Pretty thick mouthfeel, bigger than a porter but less than an impy. So creamy. I liked this!
Not my favourite style of beer but thoroughly enjoyed this. pours a dark bronish colour, with a caramel malty sweetness.

Bottle, from a friend in Denver! The pours deep brown with a small off-white head. The nose is toasted brown bread, some candi-sugar. Bubble gum. Notes of caramel and red forest fruits. The taste is much the same. Light strawberry and caramel. Sweet bubblegum and sugar. Hints of tangy cherry. Some earthy leather and tree bark. Smooth and highly drinkable for the ABV. Overall, pretty pleasing, solid stuff.

Bottle thanks to my bro jackl. It pours deep mahogany brown with a small light tan head. The nose is caramel, wood, brown sugar, chocolate, over-ripe plum, prune and candy. The taste is wood, prune, plum, leather, candy, brown sugar, spice, earth and light astringency with a dry finish. Alcohol is pretty well hidden. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Smooth, well balanced balance and pretty drinkable. Nice.

Bottle shared at CPK, London - thanks to Jack! Pours red-brown with a fluffy, light tan head. Ripe, light tangy berry nose, some plums. Medium sweet flavor, brown bread, Belgian candi sugar,ight yeast, dark cherries, slight tang. Medium to full bodied with smooth, massaging carbonation. Fairly warm finish, brown sugar, ripe plums, figs, berries. Very tasty.

Pours a cloudy, muddy brown color with a bright white head.  The aroma is filled with brown sugar, Belgian yeast, and cafe au lait, and caramel.  On the palate, there is a deeply complex sweetness that finishes clean with some mild astringency from the Belgian yeast.  The 9% ABV isnt terribly well hidden, but this is a great beer anyway.

Dark tawny brown; creamy tan head. Sweet fruity carbonated aroma, classical trappiste-y dark ale smell. Flavor - dryer than I expected, a little ashy, like a porter made with cherries. A bit overcarbonated for this strong of a beer.

Serving: Bottle via McGrupp 612.  Thanks Jon!  It pours a hazy dark brown color.  The nose is malty with lots of spicy Belgian yeast and brown bread.  The flavor has a good dose of bitterness with some yeast, spice, and dark bread notes.  It definitely has more bitterness and less complexity that I would expect from their Belgian counterparts.  Medium bodied, but high carbonation makes it lighter on the tongue.  Very nice brew.
Shared bottle. Dark brown pour with malty caramel sweetness, some dark fruit and a little spice.  A nice and tasty treat from RR.
Mahogany brown with creamy head. Has a well rounded malty flavour with rich dried fruits. Some woody dryness in the finish. Warming.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a small beigh head that left spotty lacing. Sweet malty aroma with caramel, yeast and dark fruit. Flavor was quite sweet with ripe dark fruit, caramel, yeast a bit of toffee and some spices
Clear brown. Small off white head with nice lacing. Taste is brown sugar, chocolate, some sweet dark fruits like raisins and plums. Pretty sweet. Nice caramel malt character. A very good beer!

Bottle, batch 11, from trade. Thanks to xscottypx for sending this as an extra!
Dark reddish brown with a large beige head.
Aroma: malty, fruity, pepper.
Taste: vanilla, spices, especially pepper, toffee, fruity (dark as well as dried), esters, pears.
Medium bodied+.
Nice Belgian style ale with a spicy twist.

Bottle batch 011 thanks to timfoolery: Poured a dark brown with red tints to the edges, the head is a light beige. Aroma is very sweet fruit and bubblegum. Taste is fruit with a nice sweet caramel malt and fruit yeast base.

Bottle 375ml. corked.Clear medium to dark brown red colour with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, dry, moderate yeasty, dark fruit, psicy yeast notes. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet with a long duration, tart, caramel, dry. Very balanced and a very nice beer ;-) Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20121019]

Dark red pour from draft at RR.  Big bold sour fruit taste.  Defunatley strong plum flavor.  Very well put together beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml bottle, sampled at our Californian motorhome tour. Pours brwon to light black with a 2 finger head. Nose of caramel, malt, brown sugar, liquorice, soy sauce and japanese sweet sauce (the name escapes, but it is a thick sweet black sauce - yeah that one). Medium body ith a nice and round mouthfeel. Taste is most comparable with salted caramel. Special and a definite like!

Aroma is of chocolate, dark fruit, and spices. The taste is more dark fruit and spice, very belgian yeasty, with a touch of chocolate and coffee.  The finish leaves you with a lingering coffee bitterness.  The 9.5% is very well hidden.

375ml Bottle. The pour was a murky dark brown with some red highlights around the edges and an average (1-2 finger) light brown foamy head that reduced to a thin cap with simply awesome thick foamy sticky lacing.

The aroma was a tad sweet of a dark bread malt and a earthy Belgian yeast with notes of chocolate, caramel, dark fruit (raisons and prunes) and a mild alcohol tinge.

The taste was lightly sweet and extremely malty with a note of caramel and a light fruity ester early on, becoming quite a bit yeastier with a large dark fruit presence and a strong chocolaty alcohol ending. The flavor stuck around for an average time following the swallow, with a decent yeasty, chocolate taste and a mild alcohol warming sensation left behind.

Mouthfeel was medium in body with a dry, creamy texture and a strong lively carbonation.

Overall this was an exquisite tasting brew with a creamy chocolaty, fruity flavor and one hek of a kick. I just love everything this brewer puts out and cant wait till I can sample something else from them...

Bottle @ French Oktoberfest Tasting Ulfborg, 2012. Pours deep ruby amber with a lasting head. Candy, caramel, dark fruit, prune and raisin and a bit of chewing gum. Chewy malty. Fine depth and really tasty stuff.

375ml bottle, courtesy of ablackshear.  Thanks! Pours a deep, dark brown color with a huge tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is fruity, raisin, plum.  Medium on the palate with light, soft carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, malty, yeasty, bready, more raisin, brown sugar, with a sweet, raisin finish.  Probably not Russian Rivers best beer, but a tasty beer nonetheless.

Draught @ the brewpub, Santa Rosa. Rated on 20.10.2012.
Pours a dark copper brown colour with a creamy head. Aroma of cranberries, toasted malts and nuts. Flavour is really fruity and slightly tart with plums, cranberries, raisins, dark chocolate and malts. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a dry, fruity and malty finish. Great and balanced.

Pours dark brown with a thick brown head. Nose raisins, prunes, figs and molasses. Taste is sweet with just a hint of bitter for balance. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy yet lively. Body is heavy with a long finish.

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Unclear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dark fruit and notes of liquorice. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. Smooth. 191012

Bottle @ FoneFan, 9%. Dark brown/red with medium tan head. Aroma is malt, yeast, dark fruits, caramel and a little dusty. Flavour is malt, dark fruits, yeast, medium sweet, plume, toffee, ripe fruits and caramel.

Bottle at home. Pour is dark brown with a large tan head and great lacing. Light coffee, spicy yeast, dark fruits, clove, light banana, caramel, and candi sugar in the aroma. Taste is tangy and malty up front, with notes of fruit, spice, and caramel through the middle, ending with a nice roasted coffee bitterness. Nice sticky mouthfeel with high carbonation. Sweet and very malt forward but balanced nicely with spice and fruit notes, all hiding the alcohol very well. Nice stuff.

375ml bottle from City Beer Store, San Francisco
Batch 011 - Pours dark brown with a foamy white head. Aroma of ripe fruits, syrup, toasted malts and chocolate. Taste is sweetish with some dark ripe fruits, spices, yeast and syrupy notes. Finish is sweet and malty with hints of chocolate and ripe fruits. Okay, quite balanced dark Belgian ale, but a bit too sweet for my taste.

Tap. Pours hazy deep amber with a small beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is dominated by caramel, toffee and spices including cloves and cinnamon. Flavor is medium sweet caramel, toffee, light lemon, yeast, clove. Light bitter and lightly warming finish. Complex and tasty beer.

didnt realize this was a once/yr bottle. Pretty tame strong ale. Lacking the fruity/fig/dark fruit component I was expecting and (thankfully) without the huge banana. Good beer and actually more to my liking. Dry & fairly astringent, flat flavor at the end though the esters make an appearance. Alcohol well-hidden.

Mahogany with ruddy brown edges. Boiled sweet, mottled old banana aroma. Overripe banana sandwiches sprinkled with cinammon in a warm tupperware lunchbox; ill-suited hop bitterness, cherry Tunes heat. Probably my least favourite of the RR beers sampled at the tap.

Meh. Nothing bad, though nothing overly good. Typical for style. Dark, dried fruit, caramelized sugar, belgium yeast, ripened banana and spice. Bottle from Whole Foods Soma. Nose of chocolate/cocoa, wood, umami, peach. Deep amber color going to orange. Flavor is cocoa, light tartness, chocolate, cherry, ginger ale. Light body. Pretty drinkable, tasty, and elegant. Ethereal body. Bitter finish. Very nice, and quite different from the usual in this style.

Bottle graciously gifted by Darrell. Thanks man!

The beer is chestnut / mahogany in color, with a full figured head that leaves a healthy amount of lacing on the glass. The aroma consists of yeast, malt, dark fruits, spices. The flavor is well balanced and pleasant. This doesnt quite measure up to the great, authentic versions of the style, but is quite enjoyable nonetheless. The feel is really smooth on the palate, with alcohol content well hidden. Overall, another solid effort from one of Americas finest breweries.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-13-2011

375 ml corked and caged bottle. Bottled on 4/18/12. I poured this into a Chimay glass out of respect. Garnet colored liquid topped by a creamy tan head about one finger high. Yeasty, bready, earthy, dried fruit malt aroma redolant of dried figs, vanilla bean, cocoa nibs and fresh baked bran muffins. First sip yields a silky toasted malt flavor reminiscent of currants, pecans and toasted oats. Right away you know this is a special brew. One that should be savored, like a fine sherry or rare cognac. A second sip reveals more complex notes of dark brown sugar, cardamom and exotic fruits. The finish is subtle with toasty malt and herbal hops. Make no mistake, this is world class Belgian style character coming from the West Coast.  A must for those who appreciate world-class ales. Go out and get this one boys, its worth the coin!

Simply breathtaking aroma, with layers and layers of complexity: chocolate, raisins, and ripe bananas up front; followed by layers of dark fruits, caramel, and currants; with an elegant background of coffee and spices. The taste is a tad more aggressive, with roasted malts, chocolate, ripe bananas, tobacco, and yeasty spices. It is mainly sweet in character, but it has a numbing bitter to it. The palate is medium, on the sleek side, with livelyalmost aggressivecarbonation. Far more interesting than I thought it would be, though, and already a favorite of mine.

Poured from a 12 oz, corked bottle.  Dark, cloudy brown with an amber glow.  A very creamy, tan head rises to about an inch, then slowly settles to about an 8th of an inch and never disappears from there. The aroma is that of ripe fruits, raisin, and the taste follows the aroma with a certain lingering sweetness and a medium-heavy body.  Very pleasing on the palate, tickles the tongue and yet feels so smooth.  The head leaves no lacing as I drink this, and its beautiful to watch it slide up and down the sides of the glass with each sip.  A delightful drink, and another winner from Russian River Brewery.  Im feeling very happy right now.

Pours jet black with a disappearing head, highly carbonated. Aroma of caramel, chocolate and banana. Taste follows, sweet, funky Belgian yeast. A bit overcarbonated. Not bad

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

37,5 cl bottle (9,5%) @ hotel room, San Francisco. Bottled on 18.04.2012. Rated on 18.07.2012
Aroma is sweetish with ripe fruits and candi sugar. Also some distant earthy notes. Flavour is sweet and slightly sour with brown sugar, ripe fruits, raisins and some orange peel. Foamy, creamy and rather smooth palate. Sweet but well balanced.
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark brow color with tan head. Malty sweet aroma. Belgian candi sugar, malty flavor.
My first Russian River.  Excited.  Pours dark brown almost black.  tan head with some lacing.  Aroma of dark fruit and begium yeast.  Taste is the same with banana and chocolate.  Loved it.

375 ml bottle @ Hotel room, San Francisco. Bottled on 18.04.2012.
Rated on 20120719.
Pours hazy deep dark red color with medium head. Aroma of raspberries, strawberries, herbal and floral notes, plums and sugar. Flavor of raspberries, sugar, mild sourish ripe fruits and wooden notes. Smooth sweet palate, not as sour as I expected.
5326
Aroma is dark fruit, malts and slightly perfumed.  The flavor is dark fruit, grapes/raisins, malts and a mildly tart finish.

On tap 2 oz. sample at the Russian River brewpub in Santa Rosa, CA.  Part of a 10 beer "Belgian Sampler," which is a bit much to try to keep straight, even with written notes. 

Clear, mahogany brown with tan head and excellent lacing. 

Mild aroma of yeast, brown sugar and brown bread. 

Taste of dark fruit, toasted bread and caramel malts, yeast and spice. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

180712. Bottle at hotel in SF. Pours dark brown with a medium high head. Aroma sour berries, plumes. Sweet smooth finish. Very close to a Gaulouse or an Ultra Brune. Not Bad.
Sampled in a small bottle. Pours dark brown with lots of carbonation. Malted and sweet.

Rating # 500.  Bottled on 04182012.  Pours dark brown with some red around the edges of the glass.  The bottle conditioning brings a massive ice cream float head to the top.  A really nice looking beer.  Aroma is heavy on yeast with a ton of sweetness behind it.  There is brown sugar, plums, figs, and raisins.  the taste is sweet as well and the dark fruits come out heavy.  This is very close to what id call a light alcohol quadruple.  Palate is smooth yet refreshing
Tap. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, candy sugar, malt, fruits and hops.
From Tacoma Boys: Nice grass and clove scent, with cola pour and creamy head; sweet taste of cherry and soft texture.  Pleasant example of a style I dont normally go for.  Ill return to this.
Very smooth finish. Deceptively smooth for the alcohol content. Great mix of banana and spice. Very light for a Belgian Strong Ale. Aroma and flavor improved over a 45 minute period. Solid beer.

Excellent, poured slowly into a trappist glass avoiding the sediment, looking down at it I could see the tower of carbonation slowly build the head until it covered the entire surface with a nice velvety coating, color is a deep ruby brown, aroma is fruity dont really get the spice,the taste is sweet and again fruit with spice, the feel on the mouth is velvet with a lingering taste that slowly give way to the warmth of the alcohol. Again excellent!!

Tasting from way back. A 2005 vintage.Deep, ruby tinged brown with good clarity and a fine bead. Head was thick, creamy and just off-white, but lasted little as at this stage of the tasting my glass was putrid. Spiced up fruit mince nose; savoury, sweet and reminiscent of dried figs, Iranian dates in syrup, raisins,  sultanas, ripe cherries, a little sodden earth, wood, stinging nettles and powdery cocoa. Similarly complex on the palate. Good body, light viscosity giving it an oily texture; the carbonation on the softer side giving more presence. Rough, weedy hopping and berry fruit flavours poke in amongst a mix of roasted and toasted rich malt, cocoa, dark candi, cinnamon and nutmeg spice, tamarind paste and Shiraz-esque tartness. The malt and now vinous fruit dominate and fuel the very lengthy, warming swallow. Sweet upfront, drying out considerably well for the length. Good mix of yeast, malt and hop character. This is a delicious beer, very surprising. One to hunt down again! (75cL, corked bottle)

Dark mahogany with a fluffy beige head. The nose shows banana and a hint of cherry. Richly layered palate showing chocolate, raisin and cherry flavors, but no signs of cloying sweetness. Long, complex finish.

batch 10. pours a deep cola brown with a hint of ruby. very clean and clear. massive head that just lingers forever. tons of yeast, clove, banana, and funk on the nose. a bit more subtle in the taste. nice and sweet with nice hints of citrus. hints of funk and spice. a bit herbal at the finish. nice moderate carbonation. moderate to light body. drinks easy, tastes a bit fresh, funk is far more subtle from the smell.
Reviewed on: 04-09-2011

Pop the cork and theres quite the inviting aroma of grain and cherry, leaving itself as a rich, candied pastry. The palate is remarkable: Smooth, creamy, lively, and worth a swoosh around your mouth -- force a chomp, slide it down, its all yours here so take a pick or take em all. Of course, the flavor is solid, but nothing extraordinary. I picked up on spice, but what I also sensed wasnt reminiscent of banana strictly. Its important to note that the alcohol is very well-hidden. Either this is a great ale or Ive been having some overrated brews lately ;o)

Big khaki head that stays long and blends to some thick lacing.  Smells of chocolate, spice and some solventy/boozey characteristics.  Big amazing carbonation, slightly acidic mouthfeel with chocolate, dark fruit and a little booze.  Solid beer - acidity helps with the balance of this one.

A - Pours a dark brown-black color with a bit of ruby around the edges and a big layer of frothy khaki colored head. The head fades down slowly leaving behind some thick lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of figs and raisins and other sweet dark fruits and candi sugar with some pepper and other spices, Belgian yeast, and a touch of booze.

T - Starts off with a mix of strong raisin and other dark fruit sweetness with some pepper, caramel malts, and dark candi sugar. Through the middle, some more spices and Belgian yeast flavors come through with a bit of breadiness. The finish is a mix of sweet dark fruits, Belgian yeast, toffee, molasses, and a bit of booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth and a touch thick with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nice BSDA. The balance of flavors is really nice with the dark fruits and yeast flavors complementing each other nicely.

Location/Date:Bottle on June 2nd, 2012 brought by nickd717.
Appearance: Pours a dark copper. 
Aroma: Aroma of caramel, fruit, maybe rye-ish.
Taste: Light bitterness, light fruit.
Palate:Medium light body.
Summary: First off, thanks Nick! I thoroughly enjoyed this beer.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2012 Location: Bottle shared by NickD717, 6/2/12


Aroma: The nose has lots of spice malts, cinnamon, and caramel

Appearance: It has a caramel brown colored pour with a small beige head

Flavor: The flavor, like the nose, has some sweet malts and spice to it

Palate: This one is medium bodied with a nice feel, and an average carbonation

Overall Impression: 
Thanks for flying this one across the counrty Nick!  This one was another really solid, interesting offering from Russian River.

C&C bottle, batch 010, served at cellar temperature.

Pours reddish/brown with a large foamy light tan head that leaves some sticky spotty lacing and holds a light cap.

Aroma is belgian yeast, bread, fruit such as raisins and figs, very yeasty and bready overall.  Very good strength but wish there was more going on.

Flavor is dark fruits, cherries, raisins, plums, figs, black currants, yeast, toasted dark bread, a hint of chocolate, lightly sweet with some alcohol on the finish.

Mouthfeel is thin to medium bodied, creamy at times but mostly with strong prickly scrubbing carbonation.

Pretty good Belgian Dark Ale, but Ive had better examples that are much easier to obtain for somebody out east.  Was really hoping for more due to all the praise RR receives.

Bottle at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. Really starting to get used to this glass, not sure why I like it better than my trusty old Maudite glass, but I do. I normally prefer wide-open, snifter-style glasses, big base, narrow opening, maximized aroma, but this glass just seems to fit me I wonder how it will skew my ratings vs. the old standard glass. Anyway, on to the rating.. Pours murky tawny brown, with a thin, yet highly persistent off-white head, that laces really quite well.. Nose is banana, clove, yeast, some generic spice Flavours are both drier and more complex than expected, based purely on the nose, rich salt, bacon, earth, some leather and wood, very light on the fruit, which normally dominates the "Dark Belgian Strong" category... Hmmm... No question the nose disappoints, at the same time, no question the palate surprises and intrigues... A mixed bag, not at all what I was expecting.
Tap at Russian River. Rich dark amber pour with a clingy off white head. Nose is banana and spice. Moderate palate. Taste is caramel malt and a hint of dark fruit.
Tasted as one of a flight of 17 with Kaetchen at RR. Wow, great, complex beer. Wonderful malts with orchard fruits, caramel over cooked vegetables, a bit of sour mash, drying finish. Loved it.

Bottle. 12.7 oz.Pours a cherry mahogany with a khaki, craggy, cloud-laced head. The head is massive and though it recedes, it retains fairly well throughout the session. Aroma of soft, doughy sweet malts with some raisins, Granny Smith apple, cinnamon, honey, and a hint of soft chocolate chip cookies. This is a well carbonated and agressive beer; the mouth is lively and yet retains an elegant suaveness from the malty backbone. Great beer.
Flavorful but not overpowering, nice dark ale, raisins and plums? Yeah baby

There are some hints of orange in the background, overall a nice brew, not the best but still a great brew.

Bottle from cocoapuph.  Thanks!  Pours cola brown with massive, rocky, tan head.  Tons of lacing.  Aroma of raisin, toasted malt, light pear/apple cider, and faint spice/salty smoke.  Nice complexity.  Flavor starts as biscuity toasted malt and slight fruit acidity and fades to pillowy roasted malt with trailing coffee, black olive, and dark fruit residual.  Light warm finish.  Dry with light, prickly carbonation.

Bottle. Pour is ruby/black with a tan head, good retention/some lace. Aroma of dark fruit, plums, raisin, prunes, yeast, light roast. Taste at first is sharp carbonation but mellows to plums, raisins, candy sugar, sourdough bread. Full body, sharp carbonation, creamy, sweet finish.

Notes from 10/5/11.  Bottle to tulip. Appearance is good; looks like a Belgian strong. Smell is average; nothing special here. Taste is average too when comparing it to barreled brews; slightly above average otherwise. Mouthfeel is its best feature, which let me be clear, is not a good thing. I do love the carbonation of sours though. Overall, an overhyped Russian River brew thats a disappointment - especially for the price tag.

375ml bottle thanks to thirdeye11 - batch 10.
Clear reddish brown with very little head.  Nose of candi sugar, plum, raisin, and toffee.  Flavors of caramel, dark fruit, some chocolate, and spicy Belgian yeast.  Another solid brew from RR.

Pours a very dark brown with a huge pillowy head and lots of retention. Smell is figgy, maybe a bit of banana and gum. Pretty malty. Taste is sharp and bitter off the front. Figs and dark fruit come to the middle. Sourness and coffee come through on the back. Bit rough as far as drinkability, full bodied. Pretty good beer.
bottle. pours a crisp light brown with minimal head. aroma of wood and biscut. very nice banana and orange flavor

2010 draft at Teresas next store. Nose is weak with fruity-dark cherries and nutty qualities. First sip is smooth with velvetty notes and an almond like quality. Finish is slight with boozy brandy hint.

Bottle from BevMo: Created a monstrous sizing of foam that eventually retreated while the liquid was a dark brown color. In the aroma, a delicate dash of spice from true authentic Belgian yeast comes through as pleasant malt base wraps things up. The flavor is initially sweet but has a shocking tart taste that could be due to improper shelving and being outside of the cooler. I love dark Belgian strong ales and this is just so happens to have become one of my favorite Russian River recipes.
Aroma of cloves and dark fruits, mainly raisins. The taste has a lot of esters in it, bananas, raisins and alcohol are easy to find.

Bottle from a trade. Pours a hazy deep chestnut brown with a thick tan head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has lots of dark fruit with some notes of sweet chocolate and sweet bread backed by a hint of flora. Flavor start with light fruit and flora. The finish has notes of smooth chocolate, sweet grains and light yeast notes with a hint of alcohol. Seemed a bit muddled to me.

bottle. dark brown body, almost black, with nice lacing and small head. aroma of big candied sugar, spice, clove, nutmeg...some circus peanut in the back. flavor is similar, with huge clove, bubblegum, and some sweet breads.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 A - poured at the brewery dark red/brown with no head. 

S - notes of banana and subtle spice, quiet dark sour fruits and belgian yeasts very subtle overall smell that lacks strength.

M - no carb, strong body with dry boozy ending

T - earthy tones, light yeasts, dry spices. dark dried fruits with subtle rustic tones. dry smoky ending with boos in the end.

O - good strong Belgian dark, with more of a earthy smokey tone than most. Alcohol is a little strong.

Draft @ brewpub. Is black with small but lace-leaving head. Aroma has cocoa powder, Bing cherries, and alcoholic heat, more so than expected. Strong, big body. A little hot for my taste, and that heat detracts from the experience. The dark malts are nice, though. The finish is dry but is way too boozy. This was really not in top form, the complexity doesnt even get a chance to express itself. Just begging to be bottle conditioned.

I received a 375ml caged and corked bottle from a friend in California. I poured it into a Trappist chalice.

Appearance: Extremely dark opaque maroon/purple hue. Forms a large, khaki, thick soapy head which retains quite well.

Smell: Strong Belgian notes of yeast, fruit, and some alcohol.

Taste: Belgian strong dark ales tend to be great beers, or at the very least very good beers. But Russian River Salvation is probably would I would consider the least best of the style Ive ever had and yet its still a pretty decent beer. Its just surprising how simple and bitter the palate is for the style. 

Beers of this style tend to be very fruity, malty and sweet, but Salvation is something else entirely. Its dry and bitter from beginning to end, which a significantly sharp bitterness with an astringency on the finish. While most beers of the style tend to taste like a fruit basket, this is a much more earthy, rustic palate of tobacco, leather and dry spice not unlike black pepper or even peppercorn. Theres a very general dark fruit taste, but I wouldnt call the palate fruity per se, nor can I pick out an individual flavors. Usually, beers of this sort have palates of the opposite variety with fruit first and earthiness second. Thats not to say this is a bad beer, just a little surprising considering the style.

Mouthfeel: Extremely lively with fizzy creaminess due to the Belgian yeast. Dry, bitter, smoky aftertaste that takes some getting used to.

Drinkability: One reason Im not the worlds biggest fan of Belgian beers is because of their low drinkability and Russian River Salvation plays that role perfectly. With an extremely effervescent body I find myself burping mid-swig! The 9% ABV body seems about right, though, as there is a lot of energy here. Fortunately its been brewed well enough to make use of that alcohol so theres only a mild warmth and alcohol presence throughout.
750 ml. Bottle.  Dark brown with a decent head.  Dark fruits and some caramel.  Chocolate tones.

Pow! Man, that cork flew across the kitchen. Very heavily-carbonated beer--good thing they put a wire cage on the cork on these. Pours a dark brown with a huge, frothy head that threatened to overflow the glass I put it in. Aroma was floral and fruity and maybe just a touch soapy, too. Nice combination of sweet, bready flavor with some touches of fruit in the flavor. Very smooth finish to it.

Batch 10 bottle from somewhere that I cant figure at the moment.  Thanks go to the person who hooked this one up for me.  Clear, rich ruby and chocolate color to this beer.  Huge off-white head that was somewhat surprising to see due to the smaller pop sound when the bottle was opened.  Sweet toffee in the aroma with some lighter spice character.  Maybe some clove and nutmeg.  Slightly sweet with toffee, toasted bread, and a slight spice character.  Slight bitterness in the finish with a touch of warming burn after.  To be honest, I dont feel the alcohol is masked much.  Not completely bad, though, on this colder Minnesota evening.

Bottle shared by madsberg. Pours hazy deepamber with a fluffy off white head. The aroma is lots of ripe fruit, toasted malt, dates, raisins, yeast, spices and light tobacco. The flavour is sweet toasted malt, dark berries, yeast, spice and ripe fruit. Light chili like feel. Some vanilla and has a malty bitter finish.

Batch 10. 375mL bottle opens with a huge pop and pours a dark brown/black with an enormous khaki head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, clove, sweet, toffee, and prune. Belgian spice is prominent but not overpowering, dark fruits, slight presence of dark malts, nuttiness, and some hop bite on the finish. Generally not one of my favorite styles but this is well balanced and nicely done.
Bottled, pours a black with a nice head, taste is with a bit of dark fruit and light spice to it, overall quite nice, good offering
Bottle. Pours a dark reddish to brown color. Aroma is fairly light. Some light tartness, dark fruit. Flavor is slightly sweet, malty and grainy. Dark fruit.

(375ml bottle batch 10) clear rich brown with few bubbles, almost no head. Nose of Belgian yeast, caramel, cinnamon, chocolate, raisin, graham crackers, very complex! Taste of milk chocolate, rich, Belgian yeast, graham cracker, creamy body and a great linger. Really solid Belgian style from an American brewer.

Bottle, Batch #010, shared by badnewsbeers. Deep orange-brown body, medium-thick off-white to tan head. Fruity nose with pear, grape, and red grapeskin, not too funky, also featuring toffee, candi sugar, alcohol, toast, and spice, including pepper and clove. Hints of wet socks and cola. Complex. Body with grape, brown sugar, and toast, also spice (pepper, clove), sweat, and bitterness, finishing somewhat tart.

One of the best american brewed belgian strong ales to date.  This one pours an almost black color with a tan head.  Aromas of figs, apple cider, banana,  and light tartness.  Taste has light tart, medium sweet and a very light bittering.  Balances nicely and finishes clean.
Iron abbey beer dinner.  Strong alcohol on the nose, taste of raisins, malt. Good.
Had at Russian river beer dinner at iron abbey on September 21. You can smell the alcohol. Tastes like raisin and brown sugar.

375ml courtesy of DaveytheFormer.  How have I never rated this?  Surely I have had this one before.  Dark Brown pour with ruby edges.  Fluffy off white head that quickly settles to a fine film.  Aroma is banana with subtle hints of cola.  I really like the nose.  Spritzy carbonation.   Banana, nut, toffee, clove and alcohol.

Bottle. Complex aroma of sakura cherries, figs, and dark Venezuelan chocolate engulf your olfactory senses, while hints of cloves and nutmeg dance around your nostrils. The initial metallic scents blew off quite quickly leaving this lovely bouquet of ripe fruit, chocolate and spice. Highly carbonated, the cherries and chocolate return with a bit of french roasted coffee and toast coming through on the end of the palate. Surprisingly light and effervescent for the style, but also not very hot for a 9% beer.

Light tartness on nose, dark fruits. Flavor is amazing, starts with some tartness,  then big plums, cherries, and prune flavors. Finish is very long and slips to dry finish. I really like it when theres huge malty complex flavors that would be overkilled with a molasses finish, but BAM finish is dry. Well done guies, well done.

pours molasses brown, light tan frothy head. great looking beer with nice lacing. nose- dates, plums, sweet Belgian yeast, clove. taste- nutty, bready, tropical fruit, raisins, esters. quite balanced over a long, nuanced finish. effervescent, fluffy carbonation. complex and drinkable.
Pours A dark brown with thick champagne head. Taste floral, brown malt , and raisins. Got it in a 12 once bottle for $ 9.99. It is a great beer but not worth the price.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Rich mahogany pour with a foamy light tan head. Toffee, plum, and clove dominate the sweet, decadent nose. The taste roughly the same, with sweet plum, toffee, and a sharp hoppy bite on the finish. A little overcarbonated, but smooth and feathery body. Awesome stuff.

Pours mid brown with notes of clove and ripe banana.  The yeast takes over with the notes of ripe tree fruits and light spice with a nice undertone of the sweet malt.  Lively on the palate with a nice true finish.

Bottle...awesome pop when the cork was removed.  Pours a dark brown wth ruby hues...giant foamy tan head...outstanding retention and lacing.  Aroma has raisin and currant...light sour/funk.  Flavor follows suit and adds a bit of fig and spicy hops...light fruit...winey.  mouthfeel is silky smooth and the finish is long, dry, and earthy.  Awesome beer!!  Delicate and complex!
Bottle. Pours dark amber with thick cream/white head that retains well. Aroma is dark fruit (plums, raisins), spices, and banana. Flavor is the same plus brown sugar and caramel. Very nice.
Ruby brown pour with a big off white head. Aroma is malt dark fruit. Belgian yeast funk and spice. Smooth palate. Easy to drink tasty.
Pour is a decent dark brown amber. smell is not that much with a little roast and slight sweetness. taste is similar kinda sweet a little fruit grapes and a light roast. good beer thx darn 1207

8/26/11. 375mL bottle thanks to darn1207! Somewhat hazed dark amber pour with a nice khaki head that lasts and laces plenty. Somewhat light aroma with a touch of tartness but mostly caramel, yeast character, and dark fruits. Nice flavor with a touch of tart up front, but mostly its rich caramel, tons of yeast attributes - banana, spiciness, etc., and more. Nice!

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours clear ruby red with thin off-white lacing. Aroma of syrup, honey, dark fruits, yeast and light spices. Flavour of caramel, dark fruits, syrup, honey, bananas and spices. Smooth, full-bodied mouthfeel to start, with a spicy, lightly bitter finish with a light alcohol burn.

375mL bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours a deep dark mahogany with a small ring of tan head. Delicate aroma of dark fruits, spices, butterscotch and brown sugar. Flavour brings out bananas mixed with dark fruits, toffee and some Belgian spices. Finishes with bananas and brown sugar. Medium complexity with low carbonation (especially for a Belgian Strong Ale). Very enjoyable.

375ml shared by duchessedubourg.

Appearance : Deep amber with big fluffy head.

Aroma : Nice fruits with light raisins and spices. Some roasted malt.

Taste : Roasted malt with light alcohol. Light caramel and chocolate. 

Overall : Not bad. Interesting malt with nice complexity. Nice fruity notes. Well done and quite classic.

Murky brown color, small tan head, excellent lacing... very very aromatic. belgian yeasts, traditional dubbel aroma, nice fruits, raisins, lightest chocolate... super carbonated, medium bodied... carbonation muddles the flavor a bit... dark fruits, lots of fruits, dry, nice flavor, some mild chocolates, fruity, mild belgian yeast...

Pours deep dark brown with reddish hue, white head a nd little lacing.  Aromas of bananas, lemons, and spice.  Taste is sweet with some sourness in the middle with a slightly bitter finish.  Palate is medium bodied, with some lively and somewhat fizzy carbonation that dances on the tongue.  Overall, this is not my favorite RR ale, but Belgian Strongs are not my favs anyway.  The flavor is not bad; fruity, well-hidden alcohol, nice malt blend with spices.  But still, not my style and not my favs.

Pours dark brown with a pretty decent tan head at first that dissipates into just a light dusting of a head on the beer. Purple fruit, raisin, molasses aroma. Spice flavor, anise, clove. A bit of banana working in there as well. Wild earthy yeast aspect especially on the long lasting finish that leaves a gritty texture and dirty flavor for a while. Decent body, well balanced and complex. Malt has some chewiness to it. A little bit of toffee.

Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with frothy tan head. Dark fruits, raisins, leaves. Big malt profile that compliments the aroma. Full bodied and smooth. Alcohol is well hidden. On par with St. Bernardus and Pannepot.

Murky mahogany-brown topped by a generous creamy beiged head. Lots of sediments. Intense fruity nose of grapes, plum, bananas and some spiciness (nutmeg). Medium to full body, lots of banana flavors and finishes on a light chocolate - nutmeg note. Good beer. But at 10$ a bottle, its totally overpriced and over-hyped.There are many equivalents for a third of the price. Im thinking...DeMolen Mooi & Meedogenloos.

On tap at the brew pub, served in a tasting glass. Pours clear caramel with a small, off-white head. The head fades slowly to a thin remnant. The nose has notes of toasted malts, caramel, toffee, raisin and plum, with fruit, oak and hints of vanilla and anise. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with many notes carried through from the nose. On the palate, it is light-medium in body with a smooth, milky texture with just a hint of a bite. Overall, this is a nice strong brown ale with fruity notes and oak and vanilla accents. Delicious. 2011-06-09

Aroma of dark fruits, belgian yeast, candied malts, brown sugar. Its a bourbony, sweet belgian ale with no bitterness.   Highly carbonated, caramel, banana, dark fruits, fuzzy aftertaste.  Its quite good, but having it the same night as angels share puts things into such a unique perspective.

In short: A spicy Belgian dark ale with plenty of ripe bananas.  My least favorite Russian River
How: Tap at McMenamins, Philadelphia
The look: Clear dark copper body topped by a small beige ring of foam
In long: Nose is ripe bananas and spices with some light phenolic notes.  Taste has a lot of freshly baked crusty bread, fruit cake, some toffee, browned banana peels, lots of xmas beer style spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, etc.).  I dont know if the beer is spiced but it sure feels very spicy.  I really like it at fist but by the end of my glass I got tired of the sweetness and spiciness.  Coming from any other brewery Id be pretty happy with this beer but this is right now my least favorite Russian River beer (my previous lowest rated RR was 3.8!).  And I dont believe in the a so-called Salvation.  And I also hate when people knock on my door at anytime of the day and tell me I need to listen to them if I want to be "saved".  Damn firemen.

375ml bottle batch 10. Hazy brown with a biege head. Nice Belgian yeast, spices, licorice, raisins;  fully carbonation, hint of bitterness then goes to sweet belgian with a booze bite and fizzy carbonation that prickles the tongue. Good.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2011 Bottle of 010. pours a cocacola black with lots and lots of mocha-ish head. Aroma brings to mind belgian esters and mild chocolate. taste is much more chocolate than i remember. Chocolate notes blend well with dark fruits. Very smooth mouthfeel. lower carbonation than the lighter counterparts.

Bottle was highly pressurized. but luckily didnt foam. Poured almost black, you can only see dark brown if held up to light. Tastes of apple and caramel. There is a bitterness that coats the mouth and keeps the beer from being too sweet.

Bottle served in a tulip. Beauty dark brown pour with amber hues and a huge tan head. Terrific retention. Light belgian. nutty, with bright raisin and other dark fruit notes. Very sweet flavor. Medium-full body, good carbonation, thick-creamy texture, and finishes bitter, with a hint of sour as well as some heat.

Bottle with Carla. Pours a dark nut brown with lots of bubbly brownish foam. Smells of slightly sour alcohol with hints of cherries, vanilla, nuts, Candi sugar and licorice. Tastes of chocolate oranges, cinnamon, alcohol and a hint of beets. Very flavorful with lots of bubbles.
Sweet fruity banana malt nose on this brown pour.  Rich malt flavor with roasted characteristics.

Gift from Sj. Deep brown pour with a thin  off-white head. Aroma of sweet  malt, bread and ripe dark fruits.

 Flavor is candy sugar,  yeast, caramel malt and banana. I likes it a lot.

Batch 10.  Waited a long time for this one - I have had Salvation from Avery and the collaboration beer which blends the two.  The pour is a deep crimson color with a massive, khaki, fluffy head which settles to a creamy, rocky, layer and leaves lace all over.  The nose is full of baking spices (allspice, clove, nutmeg) and banana esters, some fig, light sassafras, faint anise, some Belgian chocolate, maybe pecan.  The flavor is very similar with more emphasis on malt richness and balancing notes; fig, date, faint anise and sassafras, significant Belgian chocolate, still some clove and allspice with banana underneath, and all balanced by a moderately light bitterness from light earth, slight roast, almost woodsy.  The palate is nearly lively, full, round, and silky mouthfeel; the carbonation is a bit high for the body.  The finish is long and balanced with allspice, pecan, woodsy bitterness, and some sassafras remaining.  About what I expected from having the collaboration beer and from what I have come to expect from RR.  Very well crafted BSDA with complexity, uniqueness, balance, and deceptive alcohol.  A very well finessed beer with just enough body and yeast character to make for a great Belgian but never too bold or overdone.  The bitterness really surprised me but fell into place nicely after the malt richness and yeast/malt complexity.  RR can do no wrong as far as I am concerned.

Bottle, batch 010.  Aroma is nice and fruity, figs and raisins, pungent dose of spicy phenolics, dark sugars, light roasted malt character.  Pours deep burgundy, mostly clear, massive pillow of off-white head with amazing retention.  Flavor starts off with strong fruits, plum, raisin, figs, leading into peppery and clove notes.  Some light caramel and roast, yeasty and bready.  Light-medium body and very high carbonation, very effervescent.
Bottle shared by Maltzilla. Dark murky color, brown muddy water. Slightly fruity in the aroma, followed in the flavor as well. A little bit yeasty and bready, but good.

Thanks to someone for sharing this at the most recent Freetail bottle release party. Sorry for not remembering who provided it. 

The beer pours a deep brown color with a tannish head. I get a lot of spice in the aroma with some dark fruit notes. A very enticing aroma that also has a nice Belgian yeast component to it. 

The flavor is very similar. I get a wonderful mix of Belgian candy sugar and spice notes in the flavor. I also get some nice Belgian yeast notes as well as some raisins, cherries and other dark fruit. The alcohol is very well hidden and allows the complexity of the aroma and flavor to really come through. 

The carbonation is perfect for the style and the beer is extremely drinkable. Proof that Russian River is one of the best breweries in America when it comes to brewing Belgian-style beers.

This poured a murky dark red almost brown with a smallish beige head. Aroma was lightly toasted malts, dark candy sugar and nice belgian yeast spicieness. Flavor was a nice blend of taste between belgian sweetness and spiceness and the absolutely perfect carbonation for every Russian River beer is just amazing. Probably my least favorite of Russian River beers ive had and still a pretty solid offering.

Bottle, batch 10.  Big fluffy light tan foamy head on a deep, dark brown head...opaque.  Tart dark fruits in the aroma, yeasty, and a touch of spice in the aroma.  Dark fruits, sweetish plums, lots of spice, bitter toffee, hint of chocolate, and fruity yeastiness.  Lighter to medium body with very vibrant and champagne-like carbonation.  Pretty tasty, and never gets too sweet.  Nice brew.

Aroma of dark fruits and yeast.  Color reddish brown with persistent beige head.  Taste dark fruits, yeast, spices, coriander, a little banana.  I really would have liked some more sweetness and did not pick up much if any candi sugar.  Finish yeasty with minimal bitterness.  Alcohol evident with a little burn at the end.  Not bad but a little more sweetness would really have improved this beer.

Draft at Monks as a precursor to the madness of Lost Abbey. Pours a deep burgundy, dark brown-reddish body with nice off white lacing. Aroma is belgian candy, spice, and yeast. Mouthfeel is slightly smooth and spicy with notes of bread, belgian yeast, candy, and some dark fruit.

Bottle thanks to Owen. Pours a wonderful mahogany with dense light tan coloured head. Upon the initial pour, the aromas are dominated by licorice. This is quickly replaced by lots of dark stone fruits and plenty of yeast character. Light slightly roasted toffee in support. Flavours show plenty of sweetness up front. Some bitterness and a little alcohol burn near the finish. Medium mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Batch 10.  Poured from bottle into a tulip.  Nice dark brown color with a great holding head and retention.  Nose is dark fruit, toffee, caramel and I even get the banana they list in discription.  Taste is a whole lot of dark fruit, raisins, and toffee.  Very clean finish with very little alcohol.

Deep amber/brown clear pour off white thin head 
.... aroma of dark fruits (figs raisins), fruity yeast banana and candi sugar. ... Taste of candi sugar, dark overripe fruits figs, raisins and fruity yeast banana and a bit of spice ...  dry finish ... well balanced, sweet and delicious

Bottle thanks to Caleb.  Pours nice dark reddish with off white head.  Aroma has notes of raisin, figs, caramel, molasses, toffee.  Taste is nice with spicy pepper, raisin, other dark fruit, some sweet toffee, brown sugar, more pepper in the finish.  Nice brew, a bit pepper and carb heavy, but delicious.

bottle thanks to 50belair.  poured a really really deep amber/brown with a one finger off white head and lace on the glass.  aroma was plum, brown sugar, raisins, candy sugar, very slight smokey character, and yeast.  flavor was pretty much spot on with the nose with a nice finish.  the body was super carbonated out of the fridge, but when it warmed up the carbonation was better.  Thanks matt!!
Bottle. Pours dark and long. Aroma is musty, spicy. Taste is sweet, belgian candi sugar, plums, alcohol. Reminds me of a quad.

375 ml bottle.  Batch 10.  Pours a dark brown with a small very light tan head that sticks around for a while and leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is big dark fruit with raisin and plum, spicy Belgian yeast, candi sugar, and a breadiness.  The initial taste has a sweetness with some candi sugar then goes into some raisin and plum.
