The finish has a breadiness with some spicy yeast.  Medium body.  Low carbonation.
Pours a dark mahogany color with almost no head. Notes of spicy licorice, bubblegum, bananas foster, and booze. Good sugary long finish. Yum.

Initially appears to be very dark brown to black, but is actually a really pretty slightly murky ruby orange color with a finely laced, foam off-white head propelled by very active effervescence.  Light sour, briny and estery aromas, one of which resembles the smell of plaster.  Creamy texture with a slightly sour cherry flavor initially, followed by milk chocolate, raisins and Belgian candy sugar.  At the very end there is an earthy, rounded bitterness which stays behind on the tongue with some baking spices.   The alcohol in this is really hidden; its hard to believe this is 9% ABV.

Nice snowdrift of a light tan head on dark brown beer.  Aroma is dominated by clean banana and a mellow, underlying peppery spice.  Taste follows the aroma with a very round, banana/clove flavor up front followed by a combination of hard to identify spices before picking up spicy pepper, a tinge from the alcohol, and some sweet malt/raisin notes toward finish before the clove comes back.  Very well done.

375 ml bottle.  Pours a nice brown color, but is not opaque.  Nice light brown head that last and leaves decent lacing on the glass.  Tastes of a nice dark Belgian ale with banana, raisin, and hop notes. a very nice take on the style.  Finish is belgian hoppy, and medium, with sweetness.  Overall, a very good beer.

beautiful belgian styled ale that has amazing aromas of mild butterscotch and raisins. the taste is a beautiful smooth dark fruit flavor with hints of burnt caramel. nice hint of roasted malts. finishes nice with a mild dry clean palate.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2013 Batch 10.  I have had earlier batches that I thought were better.  Dark brown in color with a HUGE off white head.  Seriously,  almost came out of the top of the RR glass.  The nose is Belgian yeast, Belgian candies, and earthy fruits/spices.  This batch is over-carbonated!!  The taste is kind of thin with Belgian yeast, candies, bananas, and cloves running the show..
delicious dark ale. smells of cloves and belgian yeast. beutiful dark roasty brown color, with beige head. russian river knows how to make beers. tastes similar to damnation malty and bready.

Pours a dark brown color with a nice off white head. Has a slight banana smell to it and a little sweetness. Has a Belgium yeast, dark fruits with a slight sweetness to the taste. Another nice one from RR

Cloudy garnet pour beneath a tan head with all sorts of bubble sizes, good retention. Aroma is candied dark fruit, banana, baking spice. Medium-full body, light carbonation, minimal alcohol warmth on the finish. Starts off sweet and slowly fades to lightly dry and bittersweet on the palate. A good beer. Ive got one in the cellar so well see how it ends up in about a year from now.

batch 10 poured into a Darkness glass... pours a dark brown with lots of glassy amber, tons of carbonation, at least ten fingers, good cap, unreal lacing... lots of banana on the front of this, raisins, and alcohol, a little too sweet but nice...  taste is not as successful but basically the same as the nose, lots of banana, cloves, too spicy and yeasty with a light chalk finish... mouthfeel is too carbonated
Bottle, batch 010, perfect nut brown pour with creamy tan foam, aroma of malty b elgian sugar,nutty with aged fruit, flavor is balanced, fruitsmalt, candied sugar

Bottle. 12.7 oz. Split with and courtesy of Vinny for my 100th Belgian Strong Ale rating. Pours a cherry mahogany with a khaki, craggy, cloud-laced head. The head is massive and though it recedes, it retains fairly well throughout the session. Aroma of soft, doughy sweet malts with some raisins, Granny Smith apple, cinnamon, honey, and a hint of soft chocolate chip cookies. Flavor is full of apples and soft, rich, sweet breads, wtih some chocolate and dark bitter figs in the finish. This is a well carbonated and agressive beer; the mouth is lively and yet retains an elegant suaveness from the malty backbone. This is an outstanding Belgian Strong Ale, and Im proud to drink my 100th from one of the best breweries in the US. Cheers.

Bottle @ home. Ive been wanting to try this beer ever since I first tasted Avery Collaboration Not Litigation a few years back. Red/brown body with a bubbly tan head. Belgian yeasty, candy sugar, dark brown malty nose. Highly carbonated mouth feel. Candy sugar, dark malty, Belgian yeasty, sweet, tangy flavor with a quite sweet Belgian brown malty. Alcohol is well hidden behind the carbonation and abbey dubbel-like body.

375 ml. bottle. Corked and caged. Batch 010. Served at cellar temperature. Pours a thick, lasting beige head, with extensive lacing, over a reddish copper (SRM 25) slightly hazy body....nose is musty banana/bubblegum, malty with toffee/carmel, light fruits (raisin, plum), bit of cocoa, chocolate, vanilla and tobacco.....taste is slightly sweet malts to start, with accompanying very light dried fruits  (raisin, plum, fig) then becoming tart with herbal tones, finishing mildly bitter....mouth feel is light of medium, alcohol hidden, carbonation high. Although obviously a Belgian Strong Ale, this is lighter in both aroma and flavor than many in the style. It is well balanced. The malts are used with a lighter hand, so the hops do not need to be heavily emphasized either. The yeast is left with an open field. BJCP 7/3/15/4/7
Anither great beer by Russian river brewing. Nice pour medium malty head. Good overall beer

Poured from 12oz caged and corked bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a lots of beige head.  Aroma is Belgian yeasts, dried fruits such as raisins, prunes and maybe some apricots.  Taste is Belgian abbey yeast and some raisins.  This tastes almost identical to Three French Hens.  I think 3 French Hens has a touch more vinous qualities, but quite similar.

375ml bottle from bev4less. Batch 010. Pours a nearly opaque dark brown color with a generous beige head that has good retention. The aroma is moderate in strength with roasted barley, cookie dough and raisins. The flavor, like the nose, features dark fruits, roasted grains, cola and sweet dough. The palate is full and smooth with prickly carbonation.  The finish is medium with a bit of astringency. Overall: A very tasty brown ale.

good beer. I was expecting more complexity based on their other beers, however; this is still a well balanced beer that tastes great. I enjoy the proper carbonation this has, when opening the bottle it gave a good, solid pop. It smells of belgian yeast and fruit, and tastes very similarly. Overall I enjoy this beer and would buy it again if it wasnt so hard to find around here.
From a bottle,great beer from russian river i must say off the top of the bat,caramel, medium sweetness, has a very nice fruit flavor.Well worth the money.
375.  Pours deep black with ample white fizzy foam.  Aroma is of malt and rich fruit bananas and more.  Flavor is dark and rich, oatmeal, raisins, bananas and plums.  Nice, complex beer.

Tasted on 3/20/11 from a 750mL corked and caged bottle purchased at Toronado, Batch 009.  Pours hazy dark brown with a thick white head that slowly recedes to thick and even lace, leaving residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is fruity Belgian yeast with banana, spices, more fresh fruits, and a good dose of molasses and dark caramel malt.  The flavor is lightly sweet up front with dates, molasses, fig, banana, cloves and other baking spices, moving to more fruity yeast and a little bit of lightly bitter dark malt with some dark chocolate and coffee.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long slightly hot finish that runs the gamut of all of the flavors mentioned above.

12/10/10 notes: brewpub sampler. Wow, a Quad by RR?  Dark magenta-brown in color, hazy and still. Aroma has golden raisins, prunes, milk chocolate. Flavor is similar with rich malts and integrated dried dark fruit character, golden raisins are prominent. Alcohol supremely hidden. Good effort.

It pours dark ruby red/brown with an off white head. The aroma is sweet hard candy, cherries, and dark malts. The flavor is powerful with cherries, apples, licorice, rich cocoa, spicy yeast and a strong alcohol presence. It is nicely full bodied and has an alcoholic, slightly bitter finish. Complex stuff.

750ml, corked & caged bottle, batch #9 courtesy of a generous trader on BA. after muscling the cork out this one pours a dark, reddish-brown with a thick, rocky, beige head and great lacing. aroma is wonderful with beautiful fruit notes of red plums, black cherries, and sweet raisins backed by belgian candy sugar, cloves, cinnamon (definitely reminds me of raisin bread), and cedar wood with a hint of musty hay. flavor is great as well with the spicy cinnamon, belgian yeast, and raisins coming through at the forefront with notes of cherries, red grapes, wood, and sweet caramel as it warms followed by a dry, grassy, spiced finish. palate is medium bodied and creamy on the tongue with crisp carbonation and a lingering, dry, fruity finish. overall, an outstanding belgian strong. how is this not rated higher?!
7th December 2008  Cloudy brown ale. Malty and slightly chocolately like a Scotch ale but with the crispness and sourness of a Belgian. Dry semi sweet finish.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2011 Batch 001. 750 ml. This beer has held up surprisingly well. Big, frothy tan head, lasting. Brown body. The aroma has notes of  cherry, caramel, toasted grain, plums, raisins, flowers and mustiness. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly to moderately acidic. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Slight oxidation with some port notes, but the dominant aroma and taste is of tart cherries balanced with sweetness of dark fruits. Dry finish with some alcohol warming. Very nice. Thanks TAR.

Bottle pours brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of toffee, raisin, fig, and vanilla creme.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of apple.  Overall body is light to moderate, and somewhat oily.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2011 (750ml bottle from Mike batch 009)).  Pours cola color with tan head.  Aroma of caramel and some apple.  Taste is sweet with some bitterness.  Thinner bodied. Oily slick texture.
Hazy reddish brown pour with minimal head.  Yeast, spice, ripe fruit and roasty malt in the aroma.  Flavor is sweet malt and fruity.  Pretty tasty stuff!

(New Years Eve 2010 flight (2 of 3 - 10:40pm) Batch 003 - Pretty big lacey head considering the age. Dark orange body, bordering on red. Very clean looking? Malty aroma. Pretty much no hop character in nose. Heavy body. Flavors of brown sugar and licorice. There is more hops in the flavor than in the aroma. Definitely longer life than the Avery beer of same name.

Really thought that I had had this before, but now I see that I had not in fact rated this.  Medium brown, slight head.  Aroma is surpisingly malty, with notes of caramel and raisin, lots of dark fruit over a faintly Belgian character.  Flavor is a match.  Really like a barelywine with a Belgian influence.  Nice.

On tap at Russian River in August 2009.

A: Pours a moderately-dark brown with some orangish hues. A good tan head.

S: Lots of dark fruits with some raisins, candied sugars, and Belgian yeast.

T: Lots of breadiness to go with the dark fruits and yeast.

M: Medium body and quite smooth.

D: Quite drinkable, and one of the most drinkable of this style that Ive had.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-04-2009

finally got to try this thanks to a buddy. pour is a brown in color with a  thin layer of off white head. aroma has belgian yeast, dark fruit, light banana, and some spice. mouth feel is a medium with  lighter carbonation. flavor has malts, belgian yeast, raisin, caramelized sugar, and spices. very nice beer that the yeast really made.
On tap.  Dark copper color with off white head.  Dark fruity aroma.  Medium body with belgian yeast and dark fruit.  Very delicious.

RR dinner at Monks:  Poured a reddish brown color with a nice creamy head.  The aroma was raisins, sugary malts, and yeast.  The flavor was raisins, other dark fruits, sweet malts and a smooth finish.  Overall, one of my new favorite RR beers.

From notes compiled on a recent trip to northern California: This isnt really my thing, but it is an outstanding example of the style, with pears and bananas in the nose and muted hops on the palate. The body, like everything from RRBC, is silky smooth, and it pours from the bottle with a pleasantly explosive, Belgian-style head as evidence of the refermentation in the bottle.
Sampled at GABF on 9-18-2010.  Comes a dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, fruit and spices.  Tastes of dark fruit, candy and some alcohol.  Smooth.  Nicely done.

sample from the pitcher @ GABF on 9/18/10.  light brown pour with a tan head.  Belgian yeast nose with some dark fruits, grapes and apple.  spice, yeast, fruits over a medium body with sweet malts.  sweet but short finish.
Rich earthy malt character, cherries, alcohol & some apple in the nose.  Flavor is rich malt, peppery yeast, dark honey & alcohol.
Draft at the brewery. A great Belgian strong ale for me! Nice mix of sweet, caramel malt, some spicy notes and also some dark candied fruit. Right there between a quad and a BSA which is what I like.

Poured at the RR dinner at Monks to end Philly Beer Week, this beers aroma reminds me that of a Westy 12, like raisin bread with sweet pleasing notes. The color is brown amber with a generous creamy head on top. The flavors are sweet, yeasty, smooth, and again, dare I say, similar notes of raisin bread as in the Westy 12 that I have tasted. Different than what I expected considering I was thinking of Averys version and the Collaboration Not Litigation in comparison.

A: snifter. deep rich mahogany color, very dark. good off-white head. great retention and outstanding lacing.

S: black currants, belgian yeast, tons of spice, some big baked fall fruits.

T: wonderful flavors, fall fruits, apples, figs, pears, etc. clove and nutmeg. some raisins. big yeasty flavor.

M: medium to full bodied. great carbonation level. very chewy.

D: not sure if RR makes a beer that is not drinkable, unless it is a bad bottle. very nice, and well worth getting.
Bottle. Raisin in the color but banana, dark sugar and cherries. Medium body with spice and bit of sour. solid dark brown head and moderate lacing.

Bottle courtesy of smellysell from TBS.  Hot damn this is good.  Smell is spectacular, raisins and plums.  Taste is similar, and very spicy.  Maybe even a little background caramel?  Pour looks essentially purple when held to the light.  Very, very good.

Batch 2-750 ml bottle thanks to Jimmy. Pours dark brown with a white head. 
Nose is a bit sour, tart but not overwhelming. Nose seems to have some fruityness Taste is a bit vinuous, tangy, old prunes. Yeasty flavors a bit overwhelmed by the subtle tanginess. Not a sour. Maybe a bit past its drink-on date. Nice.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Brown pour with light tan head and lace. Aroma of brown sugar  and dried fruit. Flavor mirrors aroma. Carbonation is off a tad a bit aggressive.

Dark amber color. fruity and raisiny yeasty nose.  No hops here.  Just a sophisticated amalgamation of roasted malt and banana-like yeast, although it lacks the depth of its Belgium equivalent.  Besides the complex fruity esters, the body is too light and at the same time too heavy due to the excess sweetness.

Appearance: Lovely dunkel looking brew. Dark brown with reddish folds and a nice 1 finger off white crown. Like a super deep colored iced tea.

Smell: rum raison, dark malt, somewhat bready belgian yeast, banana, and a touch of cinnamon.

Taste: this is really like a dunkelweiss meets a belgian dark. banana is overly dominant as is a small amount of sweet sugar and a nice belgian yeast contribution.

Mouthfeel: medium bodied, a touch syrupy, with a little less than optimal carbonation in my opinion.

Drinkability: The abv is a bit high but nothing else holds this one back from high drinkability.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-21-2009

On tap at brewpub
Appearance:  Pours a dark ruby with a tight thin beige head.

Aroma: Juicy Fruit gum, pipe tobacco, grandma perfume and flowers.

Taste: Concentrated Juicy Fruit, dark fruit, clove and spicy yeast.

Mouthfeel: Fizzy and full bodied.

Overall:  Full flavored, full of character, and would be best pair with some cheese or dark chocolate.

750mL blind tasted with Travlr. Pours a slightly cloudy to clear reddish brown with a thin beige head. Baby lacing. Aroma is spicy, full of Christmas spices, cinnamon, juniper, but this is not medicinal and gross: there is a bright citrus character to it all full of lime peels, oily hops, curacao, and potpourri. Taste is spicy dark fruits, a little over the top on the forest floor like character loaded with pine, rainforest ionization, musty, earthy tones. Semisweet chocolate appears near the end as it warms. Palate is creamy, coating, medium-bodied, slick. Very good.

Blind tasting with tarheels86, thank you sir.  Called "Salivation" by the gf.  Clear reddish maroon, scant tan head.  Taste is bitter cocoa, black pepper, with a bitter chocolate finish.  Simple and straightforward.

A: The pour is dark brown with a fluffy off-white head, leaving some sticky lacing on the glass.

S: The nose is full of sweet malts and dark fruits. I pick up notes of plums, raisins, and maybe dates as well. There is also a touch of roast and candi sugar, along with some yeast.

T: Following the nose, the flavor opens up with a bit of roast followed by some sweet sugar and malt. The fruit character is not quite as intense as in the nose. Theres also a noticeable alcohol presence.

M: The body is medium to full bodied with an almost creamy level of carbonation.

D: One of the better Belgian styles from Russian River, but the alcohol presence in the flavor was a bit of a downer for me. Still a nice beer, however.

750 ml bottle shared by shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a muddy brown color with a tan head.  Aroma of raisins, yeast, brown sugar, spices, dates.  The flavor mutes some of those notes with an unusual dirty rainwater note, but its still not bad.  Medium-bodied, with a bready, dirty mouthfeel.  This was a little bit of a disappointment after the other Russian River beers Ive had have given me such high expectations for them.  Still a nice beer, though.
spicy creamy dough laden brown sugar beer.   bottele from hophead 22.  some dates and plum like fruit.  good stuff.

On draft at Russian River Brewing (Santa Rosa, CA): Pours out a hazy, mahogany red and topped with a medium beige head. Alcoholic nose, along with dark pitted fruits, light roasted barley, some hints of figs and raisin, vanilla and light barnyard. Flavors of barnyard, banana esters, figs, light licorice, dark malts, and light roast. A bit cloying. Medium to full-bodied with a semi-tart finish. Drinkability: A tad overrated. Paring: Chocolate truffles. Rebuy: Ok. #349 on 30032010, DG.

The taste of this did not match with the look of it, at Woodshop 5.0 .  Its dark brown with red tints.  Goregous.  But the flavor of it was more like a light, fruity saison.  It tastes fresh.  Grass, hay, sweetness, and alcohol. Effervecent.  It was good, it just tasted much lighter than it looked.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark brown color with a small beige head.  This one may have leaked during the trip from Reno to Cincinnati.  The aroma is fruity, banana, caramel malt, spices with moderate sweetness.  The flavor is noticeably malty favoring caramel with hints of chocolate.  Dark fruits are prominent as well.  The spices work nicely with this.  No sign of the alcohol.  I cant help thinking that this was somewhat effected by the trip because it seems flat to me.  Medium body and soft on the palate.

Russian River
Salvation Dark Ale Batch 009
Pours nearly opaque dark brown with a slight amber hue. Aroma starts with slight smell of cheap beer and canned tuna. Gets somewhat better. Aroma then morphs to yeast, brandy and dark fruits, but nothing too strong. Flavor is dark Belgian and yeasty booze. There is a malty flavor in there as well. This is the second time I have been underwhelmed with a Russian River brew. Why is this not as good to me as everyone else? Bummer, I was hoping for more.

Draught. Murky brown amber with thicker white head. Aroma is coriander, sweet floral bouquet and lighter sweet peachy fruit. Flavor is sweet and floral also light caramel. Finish is dry and bitter, tingles the tongue.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2010 On Tap at City Beer. Rich dark brown color with thick, creamy head. Subtle toasted malt fragrance.  Flavor begins with rich toasted malts and caramel followed by raisins, spice and potent cloves. It finishes dry, smoky and incredibly smooth. Very complex and flavorful with great balance and its not overly sweet or spiced like some other Belgian Strong Ales on the market.

A good-looking dark ale. The foam sits on the brown ale pleasantly. The smell and the taste are both sweet and somewhat spicy, but the spice favors the tongue while the sweet favors the nose. The beer has nice carbonation but gets a bit sticky. I would like to try an aged bottle, but this new one lacks a bit in complexity and finish. 

Edit: I tried this beer on tap at RR (10/19/08) and liked it even more, so Ive raised the scores somewhat. This is an absolutely delicious beer with some of the best coloring that Ive ever seen. Its brown with golden highlights at the edges. The flavor is complex, and it succeeds marvelously.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2010 medium tan foam .. light malty aromas-simple .. bold burnt sugar and bourbon whiffs .. . goes very well with melting in the summer sun brie .. . a nice powerful brew! .. . Im gonna slash and gash, cut another hole in your ass. I spill blood on the walls, then play tennis with your balls. If the phone rings, dont answer the call. Gonna slit your throat, fuck you like a goat, peel your foreskin off and make a winter coat. Peace!

Corked bottle from NickD717, thanks! Dark brown color. malt, plums, dried figs and licorice in the aroma. Malty flavor, fruity with some roast, blackberries, tannines, chocolate and dried fruit. Some earthy hops. A good balance in this abbey-like beer.
Very rich, with dark and chewy malts. Notes of dark toast, brown sugar, molasses and toffee. Throat-warming alcohol. Great texture.
Pours brown, with a solid head. Aroma is fruity, ash, alcohol. Flavor is dark, yeasty, malty, with a bitterness that sits right on top of your toungue. Finish is malty and mostly bitter.

Pours a murky dark brown with a large tan head. 
Nose is heavy on banana esters, spices, and dark fruits. 
Taste is in line with the style, nice dark fruit flavors, spicy esters, banana peel, belgian candy sugar, very tasty.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, medium carbonation with a good spicy and malty aroma.  Flavor is plum, banana white pepper, and very malty and well balanced for a 9% ABV beer.  Very good and well worth a try.

Poured dark brown with nice ruby highlights and a creamy, tan head that hung around for a while and created nice lacing.  The aroma was a beautiful blend of rich caramel malts, dark fruits and light yeast.  The flavor followed along, with an almost perfect combination of the yeast and the rich malts.  Some very pleasant alcohol warmth towards the end.  Nice, medium bodied mouthfeel.  Really good.

Draught at the brewpub. Pours clear dark reddish/brown with a moderate, lasting brown head. Aroma and flavor both have a lot going on. Dark fruits (plum, fig), brown sugar and caramel, roast malt, hint of chocolate, spiced with licorice and vanilla. Might be on the sweet side for some, but I like it quite a bit.

Bottle Batch 17 shared by alexsdad06. 

Poured clear reddish/brown color with an average brown head that lasted with excellent lacing. Very complex  dark fruit, caramel and small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy complex chocolate bittersweet flavor with medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. 

This is a standout beer.

750ml Bottle courtesy of Immy at Immys Backyard Throwdown, Batch 004. Pours brown in color with tan head. Aroma malty, caramal and spicy. Taste sweet, malty, woody, toffee and caramal with bitter finish.

A burgundy copper red ale with a thin moka head. In aroma, interesting oily cloves, caramel, fusel alcohol, and woody notes. In mouth, an oily candy suagr with orange peels, intense and lovely aniseed and licorice, alcohol warmth, very pleasing. On tap at brewpub, August 17, 2009.

On Tap at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 10/10/2008
Fruity aroma. Dark red coloured rich on the palate and very strong in alcohol with a little dryness in a crisp and bitter warming malt finish.

Bottle shared by psprings at his farewell dinner -- many thanks!  Pours a thin coffee color with a frothy tan head, kind of like a dark IPA.   Smells of molasses, floral hops, toasted malt, and clove.  Builds in flavor with the addition of a variety of dark fruits, yeast, and caramel.  Unique and balanced in flavor.

Batch 008, courtesy of cloudskipper.  Thanks Chris!  This pours a dark brown color with amber highlights and is topped with a frothy tan head.  A nice, interesting mix of dark fruits such as plums, blend with lighter fruits, most notably banana in the aroma with spices, yeast and cloves.  This really is a smooth drinking beer.  There is a touch of alcohol with an assortment of spices in the finish but it drinks easy for 9%.  A lot of dark fruit and spice flavors with banana too but Id say that is more prominent in the aroma than flavor.  After about half the bottle I started pairing this with some cheese per the suggestion on the bottle and it was in fact a good match.  Very good example of the style and flavors seem very authentic.  In a blind taste test Id probably say this came from Belgium.

Batch five bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a large off white head that turned to a thick lace. The body was a dark brown color with reddish highlights.

The aromas of dark fruits grapes and Belgian yeast were quite nice on this brew. As it warmed you did get a little bit of alcohol warmth. The flavors are like a typical Trapist abbey style dark plenty of raisins and grape flavor with the yeast adding to the enjoyment. It had a medium feel to it in my mouth with good carbonation.

A great Belgian dark I havent been disappointed with this brewer yet and looking forward to drinking some more.

Bottle - batch 007 enjoyed without Sean Connery.  Pours a dark red-brown with a trace of white head.  Aromas of vanilla, sweet malt, lilac, and plum.  The flavor is intense yet well balanced with red fruit, toasted malt, and some sweet caramel.  Very well balanced with skillfully concealed alcohol and a smooth, lasting malty finish.  Another fine effort from Russian River...
Bottle of Batch 007.  Aroma is distinct figs.  Very nice flavor Sweet dates with hints of pure licorice root.

Bottle courtesy of Immy on 07/18/2009. Batch 4. Clear brown body with a medium creamy tan head with some light floaty chunks. Sweet malty aroma with some floral notes. Sweet malty flavor, some caramel. Medium body with moderately low carbonation.

batch 005 shared by psprings at atlas...

hazy dark brown pour... nearly blackish with a big ol tan head. 

the aroma reminds me of black bread... molasses, yeast, raisins, allspice, clove, chocolate and star anise.

weird, it tastes like black bread too!... yum... take the notes from the aroma and add in licorice, fennel seed, minerals/cement and a dry crisp finish to get the flavor profile.

medium body has a light mouth feel since carbonation is prickly.

what a treat! 8/5/9/4/17/4.3
Time to catch up before BCTC.  Bottle at CL Rosso release.  Thanks to all the RBers and BAs that brought great beer.  Toasted cereal grainy sugary sweet yeasty.  Not a favorite style but nice.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/30/09. Pours dark brown, nice roated nut, banana and yeast aroma.  Very well balanced sweetness with hints of currant and clove.  Incredibly smooth and drinkable mouthfeel. 

Thinking about it now, I probably shouldve given it higher numbers, but Im sticking with my notes.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a big tan head.  Malty and tart aroma with caramel and cherry.  Malty and sugary flavor with some fruit and a hint of chocolate in the finish.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy orange with a small off-white head. Roasted malty aroma, light spiced and estery. Sweet malt flavoured, solid estery and roasted malt in a slight astringent mix. Ends phenolic and dry.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a slightly hazy reddish brown with an off-white head. Smells of honey. Sweet with some aromas of apples. Some dried fruits and a bit of chocolate. Also some alcohol notes. Residual sugars. Medium to heavy bodied. Sweet caramel finish with a bit of dryness.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2011 Tap at RR. Hazy red brown body, with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is alcohol, raisins and spices. Flavor is sweet, alcohol, dark fruits and spices. Very long aftertaste. Yummy. RE-RATE: Bottle thanks to Mashmaster. Clear red/brown body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is dark fruit, sweet fruit like banana, yeast, alcohol. Flavor is yeast, spices, fruit, raisins, alcohol. New score: 9, 4, 7, 4, 17 = 4.1

750 mL bottle courtesy of Immy at Immys Backyard Throwdown (Batch 4, bottled June 10, 2005).  Dark brown with an off-white head.  Slightly sour aroma.  Sweet taste; notes of toffee, caramel, and sugar.  Slightly sour on the back end.  A very good Belgian Strong as I would expect from this brewer.
@ Immy Backyard Throwdown. Batch 4. Poured a light brown color. Had a caramel aroma. Taste was a very strong coffee bean.

Batch 4 bottle shared by Immy at his Backyard Throwdown. Thanks! Pours a clear auburn color with a small head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of toffee and raisin. Taste is very similar with notes of toffee, raisin and bitter chocolate. Full bodied.
Bottle from Immy @ thr Throwdown.  Batch 4.  Caramel and toffee predominate the libation.  A little sweetness.  Very good.

Draught at the brewpub during RBSG09.   Hazy brown with a thick light beige head.   Intense aroma of dried fruit, caramel, and berries.   Starts sweet, with some dried fruit , yeastiness, and caramel, and finishes dry and lightly peppery.   Medium bodied with medium-high carbonation.   Very nice strong dark ale.

750ml cork and caged bottle batch 005 courtesy of BOLTZ7555  thanks Jason!  Pours a deep dark opaque brown with a thick one finger tan head that leaves behind spotty lacing.  The nose is caramel, raisins, plums and spice.  The taste is brown sugar, dark fruits, spicy yeast and caramel with a touch of booze in the finish.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Good Belgian  thanks again Jason!

Sampled via 750 bomber (Batch 07)during Dark Lord Day 09 at table 1. Pours a deep semi-hazy mahogany red colored brew with a heavy off-white head that slowly dissipated to a thin ring. Aroma of dark pitted fruits, some figs, a hint of raisin, vanilla and caramel malt, Taste is medium to full bodied, some alcohol scent, with flavors of banana esters, figs, a touch of licorice and barnyard funk. Finish semi-tart,  with a nice vanilla and dark pitted fruit aftertaste.
Nice malty aroma. Pours a nice tan foamy head. Taste is of banana, caramel, fruit. Very rich and delicious.

Bottle thanks to Snojerk321! Pours red-mahogany, moder, fizzy beige head. Nose of yeast, wood, banana bread, wine and berry. Flavor is woody and sweet, lots of candi and berry and chocolate, also some alcohol. Great balance, smooth body, vibrant as usual. Lacks that special extra, but like every RR beer Ive had, the quality is obvious from the first taste.

jdubfl was really nice to come find me and pour me a nice sample at Cigar City.  Thanks!!  Dark reddish/brown color.  Yeasty and fruity this one has a nice nose!   Flavor is sweet and quite flavorful.  Brown sugar, yeast, and a hint of tartness.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2011 Thanks jdubfl for opening this @ the BB Bolita Release.  Pours a dark red brown with a small white head.  Nose is dark fruit, yeast, and some vinegary tartness.  Flavor is similar with sugar, dark fruit, sweetness and bitterness.  Very enjoyable beer.  Yeastiness abounds, but deceptively smooth.

from old rating notes:  on tap at Brouwers Cafe in seattle before Fremont Oktoberfest.  mahogany pour with a big frothy head and tons of stick.  light floral aroma.  good yeasty belgian taste - dark fruits, light bitterness.  awesome creamy medium texture.  K7.5

Bottle courtesy of jdubfl. Pours a dark cola brown with thin white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of figs, ripe dark fruit, yeast, caramel, some candy sugar, raisins, some hints of chocolate and spice. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of candy sugar, ripe dark fruit, light floral esters, yeast, some hints of caramel and banana. Generally medium body with a pleasing malty finish.
On tap at RR. Cloudy/hazy brown color. Aroma is malts, sweet fruit, banana, raisin, and spice, and flavor is along the same lines. Very light yeast. Excellent representation of the style.

Pours a beautiful hazy tan with a thick, fizzy off-white head. Citrus and malty aroma that includes some banana and clove. Wonderful citrus blend of flavors that is accented by banana, coriander, and all spice. In the early sips, there is a bit of a sour cherry aftertaste. The roasted malt becomes more predominant as the beer warms. I was very impressed.

Bottle from my brohter, Buffalohead, Batch 005. Clear copper under a dense, rocky, tan head with outstanding lace. Complex dark fruits, dates raisins, figs up front in the aroma, folooes by caramel and some subltw spice. Medium body, slightly syrupy, soft carbonation, a nicely rich palate. Lots of sweetness starts quickly, but a gentle spicy bitterness is sufficient enough to bring on a balanced finish.

On tap at the Russian River Brewpub. Pours a deep orange amber body with lots of swirling lace after a dense, finger-width, off-white head dissipates slowly. Aroma of fudgy caramels, plums, spicy citrus, banana and sweet Belgian yeast, a light toasted brown sugar, cloves and cinnamon, and a touch of spicy licorice. The flavor is similar and just as complex in a slick, light body. Wonderful balance as all the flavors jump out during separate sips. A little more spicing than the aroma with lots of sweet malts all coming together before a tart and dry finish. Lingering flavors of dark toffees, plums, lemons, and spices last for quite awhile. Overall, a very impressive beer. Lots of complex aromas and flavors with a great balance. They all seem to come together nicely and go down very easily. Great beer.

Pours a hazy amber with a nice off white head that was creamy for a bit. Smells of figs and plums and sweet malt and some pice on the linger. Medium body with a very smooth finish. Flavor was killer.. Raisins and plums and sugar and oddly enough I got some type of earthy tones on the back end. Wish I could pin point it more.. It was not oak or smoke but earthy and very cool!! There was some spice and maybe a hint of pepper.. I would have no issue knocking this tasty treat down again!

Bottle of batch 8 (I think 2 and 3 made appearances, but I only tried the 8 after a few others mentioned that 3 had oxidized) at the Drink for Charity event at Rattle & Hum.  Pours a nice hazy dark brown with a thin tanned beige head.  Nice bit of funkiness and some sweet prune notes.  More prune and plum flavors.  Finishes light and crisp with a little bit of sweet malt.

750ml caged and corked bottle (Batch 007) served in a tulip.  This beer poured a dark mahogany brown hue with a one-finger thick head of lasting tan foam.  A nice coat of lace was left around the glass.  The aroma included caramelized sugar, woody vanilla, and dark fruits.  Also some spicy/clovey yeast.  The flavor had strong caramel, candi sugar, raisins, and vanilla.  There was some mild chocolate and clove in the finish.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and had light to moderate carbonation.  An interesting take on a dark Belgian Stong.  Definately not a bad beer, but not my favorite from Russian River.

I some how got to sample this awesome beer at DLD 09. Dark brown pour with tan head. Aroma is estery, with a lot of bananas.  Kind of funky, kind of fruity flavor, with some wood. Great beer, enjoyed it a lot.
Aroma is sweet and fruity with a little barnyard and awkward malts. Taste is a little funk and rotten malt and wood. Some dark fruit and lively carbonation.

On draft at Teresas.  Poured deep brown with very thin tannish head.  Complex, sweet flavor of dark fruits (plums, figs, raisins) and black licorice.  Very dubbel-esque.  Another treat from Russian River.

Draft at The Bishops Collar in Philly. Pours amber brown with a beige head. Malty sweet aroma with raisin and other fruits, spices, and toasty hints. The flavor is malty with dark fruits, golden raisins, toast, spices, and hints of lighter fruits like peach and banana. Very good.

tap at falling rock.  coffee color with thin dense creamy head.  coffe, dark fruit, liquorice, musky intense aroma.  rich creamy mouth.  complicate palate.  big malty monster wit raison, yeast, banana.  hint of coffee.  rich, rich, rich.

Bottle. Aroma of Fig Newton (yes, both the fig and sweet, doughy malt), an intriguing spice profile of clove, maybe some ginger-ish, maybe just a touch of mint, sweet fruits. Flavor starts off with that spicy kick, but the doughy malt really comes into play nicely and some chocolate and toffee notes then start to play out as well. Really a pleasure to drink, a nearly full-bodied BSA that is still remarkably smooth with an earthy sort of finish. I can only imagine how much Id love this beer is BSA was actually one of my preferred styles at the moment...more of this beer might even make that happen.

Bottle courtesy of iowaherkeye.  Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of spices (clove and something else I cant quite figure out...).  Flavor is spicy initially and then some roasted nuts and smokey notes make their presence as the beer warms.  Tastier and tastier as I keep drinking.  RR certainly makes some top-notch beers.  Excellent beer, hardly even tastes like a typical BSA.
8/4/8/4/16 (4.0/5)
Crushed with Jakebra at BSAF.  Dominated by a musty, woody nose and flavor.  Some nice sourness in the finish.  Interesting Belgian strong.  Pretty nice.

This bottle was part of my stash I had shipped from RR to a relative in Minnesota and then my wife brought it back in her luggage from Mn along with 11 other RR bottles. The things you have to do to get great beer when living in Pa. Batch 001. This beer poured a brilliant dark amber color with a slight tan head. The aroma is a bit malty, caramelly and with a touch of fruit, maybe raisins. You also get a bit of the abv in there. Very pleasing to my sniffer. The taste is big. There is a great malt backbone with more raisins and figs. I also got some toasted notes, a bit of chocolate. The body is medium and makes for a pretty drinkable beer, even with an abv of 9%. Another fine beer from RR.

750ml bottle batch 006 courtesy of swnicholson, thanks! Dark brown color with red tints where the light hits the edges with a solid foamy head. It smells like a fruity Belgian dubbel,apples, nice. Wow, the taste is malty, fruity and very delicious. This is complex much like the other RR beers Ive had yet still easy to drink.

12/21/08 batch 007

nice, heavy black licorice at first, good flavor, I wish we got this and perdition in addition to the beers they currently distribute to Colorado.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-15-2008 01:43:46

On tap at Belmont Station, Portland.  Dark brown-amber with small head.  Sweet ripe bananas, wheaty, fruity.  Flavors of banana-flavored candy, cloves fruit, big malts.  Became more alcoholic as it warmed.

[Bottle] brought back from S.F. Pours a deep brown with a medium, creamy tan head. Aroma is wheat malt, yeast, clove, some mustiness, and a touch of banana. Flavor is really interesting. It starts out sweet with some chocolate, prunes, and other dark fruits, and towards the back of the palate completely changes into a dry, somewhat bitter and chalky, and roasty beer. There is a hint of alcohol on the finish as well.

Pours a cloudy dark brown-black with no head. Odd cheesy aroma, coffee/latte. Tastes like a latte with more of that cheesy taste. Roasty chocolate. Thick body with decent carb. The cheese thing is a bit off-putting, but I like the chocolate notes. Odd.

750ml thanks to iowaherkeye.  Pours dark amber with reddish hues, and a creamy tan head.  Great retention and lacing.   Aromas first and foremost, nuts, a huge nutty aroma.  Other aromas include bread, dark fruits, yeast, and a slight alcohol burn, hardly enough to mention though.  Flavors of sweet malts and dark fruits up front with a caramel and spice finish.  Palate is nice and smooth, well carbonated.  Thanks again Joey.

My 100th Belgian Strong Ale rating.-   -   -On tap @ the brewpub. Pours deep dark clear amber with tan head and spotty lacing. The aroma is full of dark fruit and smooth tartness. The taste begins with bold rich dark fruit from prunes, raisins, plums and green apples. It then moves into apricot and pear skin before the mild tartness and sourness dries it out. It becomes very well balanced and demands additional samplings. Say YES to Salvation.

On tap first at the Green Dragon in Portland and then a week later at the brewpub in Santa Rosa. Dark reddish brown pour with a two finger off white head. Big aroma of biscuity malt, plum and cherry with some pine spiciness in the smell as well. Nice alcohol and fruit flavor with a big malt backdrop and a very mild citrus and pine in there as well and a surprisingly sweet finish. One of my favorites that I sampled at the brewpub, and I picked up a bottle for only 7 bucks at bottle barn to bring back to Oregon!
Flaske. Uklar mørk brun i farven, lille råhvidt skum. Dufter og smager af nødder, mørk sukker er syrlige noter og med en let syrlig eftersmag. Ikke tosset.
Bottled. Quite well balanced. Hazy and dark brown coloured with a medium sized head. Malty, nutty, caramel, hops and a faint hint of sourness. Nice.
Poured dark  with an off white head. Smells of hops with sweet oaky notes. Palate was lightly carbonated. Tastes of nutty, smoked coffee. A slightly bitter aftertaste. Smooth finish.

Deep amber hue, moderate off-white head dissipates, good clarity. Nose is sweet rich bready malts, dark fruit esters, moderate hop bitterness and spices, alcohol. Flavor is sweet malts and dark fruits, medium hop bitterness and flavors, smooth alcohol warmth and spices midway, finishes lightly sweet. Medium-full bodied, smooth texture, high carbonation. Overall a fruity and malty strong Belgian with good balance and drinkability for this abv.

Tap @ Belmont Station...  Poured deep brownish/ruby with an off-white head.  Fresh, malty aroma that also had a metallic character.  Chalky flavors of smoked malts, toffee popcorn, and nutty, coffee flavors too.  Maybe prunes or other dark fruit notes in the finish.  All the flavors seemed to have worked great together in a subtle way.

One hell of a Belgian-style strong dark ale. In the same class as Allagash Four. Dark copper color with a small but lasting off-white head.  Aroma is malty with dark fruits, spices, and some yeast.  Flavor of caramel malt, molasses, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, and lots of spices.  Fairly full body.  One of the best ones I had at RR Brewing Co.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2010 bottle thanks to Secret Santa.  Pours a dark brown-black with a huge tan head.  Nose is of vinegar with a sour musty smell.  Taste is of raisins, roast malt and spice with an underlying hint of sourness.  Mouthfeel is medium with a dry, sour tartness and lots of carbonation.  Dont know if this one was supposed to be sour.  Maybe it was infected.

Draught at TND:  Faint aroma of yeast, currants, slight dark ripe fruits, and slight sugar.  There was really very little scent; I even had others smell it.  Poured deep amber/medium brown in color with a small, creamy, off-white head that lasted throughout, especially around the edges.  Light to medium sweet flavor.  Tastes of caramel, slight smoke, slight bacon, malts, slight toffee, slight nuts, and light candi sugar.  Medium to full body.  Sticky texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Malty, sticky, slightly dry finish.  Very drinkable.  9%ABV is well hidden.
Pour from the tap at OBriens. Dark brown with a tan head. Very silky smooth in your mouth. Rich malty with dark fruit and some spice. Alcohol well hidden. Very tasty brew.

Tap at RR.  Pours a deeper brownish copper with a medium creamy off white head that left great lacing.  Aroma of molasses, toasted malt, dark fruits, Belgian yeast esters and toffee.  Flavor of various spices, brown sugar, earthy, doughy, toffee, dark fruits, dry and biscuit.

A: malts at first, then hops and spices. V: dark brown with a small head, clear body and a hint of a red tinge. Taste is of dark fruits, mild hop body. Somewhat barley and a touch of alcohol. Full palate.

Deep ruby coloured body with a thin off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, cherries and some wheat. Medium-bodied; Nice tastes of light sweetness intertwined with maltiness along with some nutty flavours. Afterstaste shows more of the same, and a good yeastie flavour at the tail-end. Overall, a good beer - definitely worth trying if you can find it. I sampled this 375 mL (split) bottle purchased at Norms in Vienna, Virginia on 22 December 2006.
3 yr old bottle of Batch 8.  Pours real dark brown almost black.  Nice roasted malt flavor with some chocolate.  Nice dry finish.  Really smooth and good.
Draught, dark brown color with a sugary malt aroma.  Initial taste of sweet malt with some bite, dryness and rich roasted flavor.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2009 Re-rate 6/09: Bottle sample. Thanks Yafit!  Deep ruby color. Aroma of caramel, licorice, raisins and prunes. Sweet flavor of dark fruits, licorice, yeast, spices, demerara sugar and a bit of alcohol. Medium to full body. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

 (10/28/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Santa Rosa. Nice deep amber color. Aroma of malt, caramel, smoky wood notes and lots of dark fruits. Sweet malty flavor with dark fruits (plums, raising, figs notes), caramel and light roasty chocolate hints. Rather full-bodied. Very drinkable for a 9% beer. 7/4/7/4/15=3.7

On tap at Falling Rock in Denver. Pours a dark reddish-black with a thin off-white head. Aroma is sharp, almost sour, of malt and dark fruits. Big taste, of malt, wood, toast, dark fruits, spices, and brown sugar. Lingering spicy malt flavors. Very tasty.

On tap at the brewery.  One of the best Belgian Strongs I’ve had the pleasure of putting my trembling lips upon.  If beer could approach the sublime of deification, this brew would be the manifestation of its’ name.  Wow!

750 mL bottle poured into a goblet.  Dark ruby brown with a beige head that leaves thick lacing.  Aroma is sweet with a surprising tartness.  Brown sugar, licorice, dark wheat bread, raisin, plum, banana, pudding.  Flavor consists of a nice blend between maltiness and esters, accented with an oud bruin tartness and some phenolic spices.  Very full flavored and full bodied, with the fine carbonation found in all RR Belgians.  Awesome beer, and one that can go head to head with a lot of genuine Belgian strong dark ales.
750 ml thanks to Jason for bringing this beer from his side trip to Russian River for me. Flavors of roasted malts and clove. Very good.
Pours out dark brown with little foam. Smells of burnt dark fruits.  Taste of malt and spice. Rich complex roasty taste. Nice brew, not too sweet, but slightly funky. Great to drink.
750 cork & cage. pour dark brown with big off white head. aroma is dried fruit and malt.  mouthful is robust with big dried fruit and a crisp hop finish. nice Belgian but not a shining RR best.

Tap at Falling Rock.  I dislike this beer.  Heavily malty an GRAINY in the aroma and flavor.  Also tastes of char, bourbon barreling, and olives that have the skin of concord grapes.  Color lacks the brightness a dark Belgian should have.

Draft at Stone. Pours brown with ridges of different shades. Smell is Belgium yeast and banana. Complex flavors of sweet Belgium yeast, various dried fruit (apricot, banana). Very smooth and drinkable. Alcohol very hidden.

Bottle shared by Thickfreakness.  Thanks Charles!  
Pours a rich dark brownish black  color wiht a beige head.  Smell is bittersweet raisin, belgian yeast, and candi sugar.  Taste is lightly spiced, a bit sugary and sweet with some dark dried fruity flavors.  Balanced flavor for the most part with a medium mouthfeel.  Very good for the style.

750ml, batch 7.  Pours a dark cola brown with a firm, bubbly off-white head with very good retention and lacing.  Aroma is strong.  Notes of dark fruit, licorice, slight chocolate and roast, currants.  Intriguing blend of aromas.  I like the chocolate component of this beer, which is more prominent than others in this style.  Its almost intense enough to think of this as a blend of a Belgian Dark and some kind of stout.  Taste is very similar to the aroma.  Smooth, slightly chocolatey.  Not so much dark fruits as a graham cracker type flavor.  Rich yet somewhat dry and a quick finish.  This is like if you took a Rochefort 10 and a good porter and mixed them 50/50.  This is unique, drinkable, and somewhat fabulous. Of the several non-sour Belgian style beers Ive had from Russian River, this is by far the best.

Draught at Falling Rock Taphouse, Denver. Clear brown - white head. Berries, licorice, metalliic notes, brown ale notes, yeasty, high sweetness, raisins, roasted, high malty. Lovely smooth fullbodied.

Aroma of malts and funk blend perfectly.  Raisin malt funkyness, makes it simple yet very complex when you chew it over.  The fruitiness / raisin flavors make for a unique beer with the Belgian yeast funk.  A great beer.
On tap at the Falling Rock (post-GABF 2008). Deep mahogany red-brown. Very rich and complex, lots of sweet malt, pruney, cigar box, molasses and spice. Absolutely delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 Batch 005 bottle from mreusch, thanks Matt!  Poured a deep brown color with some deep red edges and a pillowy beige head that faded to a layer and left nice lacing.  Slightly muted aroma with some soft brown sugar, some clove spiciness, banana and raisin, and a hint of Belgian yeast.  Smooth, moderately sweet entry that leads into a sweet hit of brown sugar and some soft caramel that transitions into an earthy, spicy hoppiness with some grape and fig as well as a moderate dry yeastiness on the finish.  Moderate carbonation and nice mouthfeel with a decent dryness.  Got much better as it warmed.  Thanks again Matt!

Batch 5.  Very attractive dark mahogany colored ale, with an authentically Belgian looking head that lasts and laces well.  Nose lacks depth and descriptive character.  Has some nice elements of dark fruit and toffee, but it lacks intensity and complexity.  Batch 5 seems like it’s not a great batch.
Draught. Low and quickly disappearing off-white head. Pitch black body. Vineous caramel berries aroma. Alcohol dominated falvor of roasted malt and caramel. Low carbonation. Long dry aftertaste.
Tap @ RR. Clear light brown color, short head. Aroma is quite hoppy, slight caramel, bit spicy. SLight alcoholic taste, bitter. Has some whisky/bourbon notes. Nice.

Sampler at the RR Brewpub (Santa Rosa, CA). Pours an iced tea browish copper with small satisfying head. Belgian sweetness, dark more chocolately notes and dark fruit sweetness mixed together. Taste is similar, bringing in ample flavors, the fruit and chocolate mixed with some caramel sweetness and brown sugar. Zesty belgian spiciness kicks in, finishes smooth and warming. Cheers

Pint - Eastside Club Tavern - Olympia, WA
Aroma  Nice Belgian yeast aroma with the dark malts lingering.  
Appearance  Dark amber in color, clear, with a thin head.  
Flavor  Has some molasses and caramel flavors along with the malt and Belgian yeast.   
Palate  Great Mouthfeel, Good texture with a dry finish. 
Overall   A very nice Belgian beer.  I was impressed with this beer.  Had some very nice qualities and held up well for being almost a year old.

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours an extreme dark brown, with a small tan head.  Spiced aroma, cloves, mints, along with some sweet chocolate.  Medium body gives way to immediate sweetness, brown sugar, cola, lots of malts.  Great, spicy finish.  A winner.

Bottle (batch 3). Poured brown with thick off-white head that left some lasting and good lacing. Caramel and spice in the aroma with a slight fruitiness also. The flavor has caramel, fruits, brown sugar and a hint of hops. Medium body, sweet throughout, smooth. Nice!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 750 ml bottle - batch 5; thanks to annapolisbeer for the trade; pours clear brown with off-white head and minor lacing; chocolate, spice and touch of sour; flavor a little mild for RR, but love the texture going down; very nice

Original Rating 9/30/08 (Overall Score: 3.9): draft @ uber - dark brown with rose highlights; mostly clear with minor lacing from the thin, white head; aromas of caramel, spice, chocolate; rich and smooth; flavors are on the sweet side with a dry finish; texture slightly creamy as it warms; brown sugar with a little bit of spice; very nice

The nose is strong in the malt department, there is also some dark fruit like cherries and current, along with a little booze. 
Dark cola color: clear dark brown, with a white frothy head. Nice sticky lacing. 
Strong chocolate flavor upfront, malty acidity follows, creamy milk, cherries and strawberries.
Palate is thick and easily drinkable.

Last drink of the afternoon - did not take tasting notes because I was too tired from playing air guitar on the stage at the brewpub with my fellow jackass brother-in-law.  Just wrote down the score breakdown while the rest of the customers stared as us whispering what I thought I heard "....something...something..retards...somethi Good Times.
Tap at Toronado SF. A very excellent brew. Can’t even describe the flavor, just awesome. Brilliant color as well. All around a great beer.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle Batch 007 thanks to Taverner. Pours a dark brown with a good size tan head.  Aroma of yeast, banana, and some spices.  Alcohol was very well hidden and this is a good representation of the style.  Well done.  Great flavor from the banana, brown sugar, and everything else.

On tap at San Diego Brewing Co., a surprising find there.  Color was dark, reddish-brown with a thinnish off white head.  Aroma of caramel, banana and fruit.  Flavor was of dark fruit, caramel, yeast, brown sugar.  Alcohol well hidden.  Nice version of the style.

Batch 006 courtesy Beerlando. Reddish brown pour with a thin white head. Malty fruity apple sour aroma. Nice malt body and lots of dark fruit notes combined with hints of caramel and some sour. Finishes very clean. Really nicely balanced, another great beer from RR.

Draft @ Brouwer’s. Deep garnet color with a rocky head, nice lace. Good aromas of dark raisons with earthy brown sugar and spicy yeast. Medium body. Flavors are rich, earthy dark malts with molasses and rootbeer spice. Is there any beer style these guys can’t get right ?? awesome stuff.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours clear brown with an off-white head.  Rich, dense aroma of brown sugar, corainder, clove, and a bunch of sweet malt.  The flavors follow through without being heavy-handed or syrupy in the mouthfeel.  Malt, caramel, figs, yeast, banana, cinnamon, and even some hops all shine.  Very, very, good beer.

750 ml bottle.

This is a darn high-end BSA. I really like it. Nice deep brown pour with an absolutely beautiful head, gorgeous beer. Nice mix of brown-sugar sweetness and spicy yeasts, touch of hops to close out cleanly, this flavors absolutely hit the mark for the style. Lovely.

(Finally) on tap at Brouwer’s. Wonderful stuff. Nearly identical to SB Abt. 12, with a few key differences. It isn’t quite as refined - it’s a tad bit lighter (weight-wise, not color-wise), and leaves your palate a bit cleaner than the SB. Pours very dark - nearly black - with that classic Belgian head. Sweet malts, raisins and brown sugar abound, with a slight edge of hops - more so than the Abt. This is the Russian River I’ve been waiting for - far better than Damnation.

Batch 006.  In a night of Belgian Strong Ales, this one shone bright.  Ive come to expect nothing less from Russian River.  The dark, translucent, ruby red body is capped by a small, foamy, beige colored head.  Spotty lacing marks the glass.  The aroma shows notes of burnt caramel, stewed raisons, figs, and a dry, dusty yeast.  Hints of earthy yeast and caramelized banana lend depth, while vinous notes add a dry, slightly sour depth that really sets this brew apart.  Flavors follow suit, with the sweet, caramelly, dark fruit base balanced by the dry, funky yeast and lightly tart, vinous notes.  Medium-full in body and smooth, the dry yeast again counters the malty sweetness quite well.  Overall, this is another great beer from Russian River.

On tap at RR brewpub.  Was a pleasantly surprised by a brown sugar and banana flavor that was just the right sweetness.  A nice medium-full body with good carbonation.  Looked quite beautiful too even in that small 3 oz. taster.  Oh well.  brought back a 750 mL for a more complete rating later on.

On tap at Toronado. Pours a dark red/brown with creamy off-white head.  Dark fruit, raisin, plum, cinnamon, clove, a hint of berries, and finishes with apple and a bit of hops.  This is an excellent beer, well worth buying.

1 pint, 9.4 fl oz. bottle purchased at Raja LLiquors in Livermore. The pour: deep dark color, but not translucent! The bouquet: raisins, subtle cloviness, cinnamon, allspice. The palate: definte roasted malts, a nice smokiness to it. nice sharpness in the immediate finish. The finish: toasty.. that’s all I can say. A high quality brew, kudos to Russian River Brewing!

Raisny cinnamon nose, with a hint of clove.  Deep dark brown color with some red hues.  Cream colored head that lasted forever, great lacing.  Brown sugar syrup sweetness, balanced by spices, slight bitterness, and warming alcohol.  Creamy full body, tight effervescence, alcohol burns through the whole thing nicely for a long satisfying finish.  Excellent beer, complex and well-balanced, no one characteristic dominates--great beer!

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2008 On tap at Live Wire, Thanks Naven for the post, I would of never thought Live Wire would have this on tap.  Awesome brew.  Reminded me of the Ola Dubh.  Smoke, sweet liquor oder.  Complex and a great finish.  Seemed a bit sweet which is great as it shows I shouldn’t open any of the bottles I have for a while.  Great future ahead of this brew.  Very cool and rare brew around these parts, Thanks Live Wire!

Re-taste from bottle.  I liked the bottled version better.

~Pours a dark brown color with thin off white head.
~Scent of coriander and yeast.
~Strong coriander and banana yeasty taste.
~Creamy feel, light alcohol tingles on tongue.
~Not really my favorite style of brew, but it does go really well with some foods with garlic.

On Tap @ Live Wire.  I love this beer, I truly do.   It’s a solid Belgian Strong Ale.  Dark colored, viscous, yet very drinkable.  Kind of reminds of a cross breed of a Saison, Stout and a Quad.   Really good.

On tap at Beveridge place. Pours dark black that you can barely see through, off white thick head. Slightly hoppy, slight chocolate aftertaste that lingered on the palate with the slight hoppiness. Spicy flavor. The belgian characteristics are are not very forward which I like, it does not have that overwhelming belgian beer tatse. Great beer way better than I expected!!!

On tap at Brouwers. Pours a dark shade of brown with a nice lasting creamy head. The aroma is a nice combination of yeasty esters, dark malt roast and sweetness, and a pleasant spice. The flavor is similar with dark malts, dark fruit, and a slightly earthywoody hop character. A pleasant yeasty spice rounds it out. Light carbonation and a fantastic smooth creamy body.

Draft at Brouwer’s. Pours opaque, slightly grainy black with a dense, creamy, lasting tan head. The nose shows a mild tartness reminiscent of highly acidic coffee beans, though not the deep kiln-roast note that comes with every ready-to-grind coffee bean you’ve smelled. Some semi-neutral dusty or CO2-y note in there as well, probably the booze. Nice creamy body with very soft carb. Sweet black bread, tart coffee, dark nuts, and figs on the mid-palate. Mild black bread finish. Great effort.
Dark brown, dark fruits, roasted malts caramel, grain, yeasty, slight alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 Batch 005 (if I can read my hand writing correctly). A great Belgian that went quite well with the steak I browned and caramelized onions. Pours with a rocky, off-white head covering a near black body. Aroma of rich bananas, raisins, and currants. Taste is quite solid wheat, banana, tobacco, belgian spices, raisins and dark fruits. Light carbonation, very good beer. Batch 10.  Not quite as good as Batch 005. Beautiful deep mahogany body with a huge and thick, tight, lace inducing tan head of foam. Aromas of dark toffee, plums, vinous, esters, phenols, spice (sort of like a cara rye or wheat). Huge fruit driven yeast and caramelized malt flavors. Plums, figs, persimmons, lightly floral or rose like. Flavors are hugely estery with malt sweetness, raisins, deep character of both malt and yeast. Plums, dark fruit, alcohols, phenols, peppery, vinous licorice. Great beer once again.

25.4 oz bottle, batch 002.  Dark, burgundy brown with a thick, dense beige head.  Nose is fig, dates, musty caramel and pineapple.  Smooth and kind of milky with buzzy carb.  Taste is raisin and woody apple with yeast and green blueberries.  Nice combination of sweet, half-sour and bitter notes.

Thanks to Electic for this bottle, batch 002.  Pours dark brown with a small light tan head.  Aroma of cherries, sherry, wood, tobacco, raisins, dark fruits, definitely wears age well.  tastes also of sherry, wood, a sort of oaky tartness, cherries, raisins, finishes with a strong wood flavor and blackberries (no, not the phone).  Medium bodied, well carbonated, but it’s missing some creaminess in the texture that I’m assuming was once there.  Pretty nice though, a very elegant beer.
Bottle, thx Omhper! Dark colour. Special B-malt in aroma. Lots of banana, fruit and candy-esters. Slight harshness (perhaps from a slight overuse of Special B?). Wow, so good!

750ml bottle batch 005.  Poured a dark brown almost black with a thin beige head.  Light lacing was left on the tulip.  Aromas of dark fruits, cocoa dust and toasted malts.  Flavor had tons of dark fruits and banana with some spice and Belgian yeast on the finish.

25 oz bottle, Batch 001, via Odeed.  Pours a dark amber body with a one finger fizzy beige head that retained as a thin film.  Very strong pop of the cork, but no gushing.  The nose is richly malty with lots of dark fruits, over ripe bananas, lots of yeastiness, and a touch of alcohol.  The flavor is pretty rich and dominated by the yeast character.  Very fruity and spicy with banana and dark plum skins up front, then the alcohol seems to take over towards the finish.  This almost seems like its a little over attenuated, leaving it feel a touch thin in the body and very airy for such a high ABV beer.  When the fizzy spritzy carbonation combines with the high attenuation it makes it feel even lighter and more airy.  A good bit of both alcohol flavor and warmth on the finish.  This was a very nice beer, but I would like to try a more recent batch to see if it has a fuller body than this batch has now.

750. Pours dark amber with a lacy off-white head. Medium body. Spicy, malty aroma and taste. Dry finish.

Bottle, courtesy Tony at Oldsmar Tap House. Dark ruby brownish pour. Thick creamy white head, and a huge amount of lacing. 750ml bottle(Batch 3)-A medium to dark ruby body with a nice tight small off white head. Aroma of belgian yeast, malt, sweetness, and caramel.
