On tap at pub. Dark chestnut and scotch color. Nose of rasted malts, molasses and caramel. flavors of rich molasses, figs, candied fruits and belgian yeast. Really good.

2005 vintage tasted on 5/17/08, thanks to derkruk and crew!  Once again a lovely dip into the Belgian world via Vinnie.  Not as complex as others, the light fruit and slight dirt flavors blend together well overall in this one.  A little hint of roast is hidden deep within as well.  Good stuff, great aged.

Thanks again to Taverner for this bottle!!!  This one doesnt quite have the pillowy head of Perdition but the lacing almost makes up for its short-comings.  2-finger cashew-colored foam sits atop an almond brew.  Aroma is a cross between a traditional Belgian Stong & Hefe.  Banana, nutmeg, and a hint of clove are noticeable on the nose.  Toasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, and belgian yeast again rear their head.  The 9% is invisible, which of course, is awesome.  Dont let this one sneak up on you!!!

On tap at the brewpub in Santa Rosa.  Dark chestnut with mahogany highlights and a thin, fine, lacey white head.  Dark malt sweetness with some alcohol, "Belgian" fermentation characteristics, light banana, spice, and molasses.  Flavor delivers more of the same along with some roasted smokiness, malt sweetness, and alcohol.  The body is warm with alcohol that is still well-balanced despite being huge.

batch 002..thanks irishboy
interesting banana nose and good malt complexity with a mildly sour mouth feel....interesting...would like to try a fresh bottle for comparison

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2008 Bottle, batch #1 shared by beastiefan2k.  Brown / amber clearish pour.  Aroma is sugar malt, ripe fruit.  The fruit is pretty nice in the flavor also, but overall the beer is too sweet and I didnt notice any other complimenting flavors.  Re-rate, June 2008, draft at the brewpub.  Light brown / amber pour.  Aroma is dark fruit, sweet malt, candy sugar, brown sugar.  Flavor is the same with some alcohol and a little toasted malt presence.

Bottle Batch 1 at Pauls Hoboken Gathering: Copper pour with a fizzy tan head. Nose is slightly oxidized. Old/over ripened fruits in the aroma.The flavor has some of those over ripened dark fruits, along with some spearmint character. Some residual spices are evident into the finish. I didnt pick up much from this one; I want to revisit it for sure.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with 2 fingers of off white head around the glass.  Flavor is fruity, belgian yeast, bannan, cinnamon, and other spices, and just a bit of etoh in the finish.

Bottle courtesy gunhaver. Pours a clrear dark amber with a one finger lasting light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, spicy yeast, caramel, and cinnamon. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and well hidden alcohol. Very good.

Oh man, this was one tasty brew.  Without knowing it came from central California, I would have never guessed it wasnt poured from a trappist bottle.  Reminded me of a Chimay red or something similar.  Dark ruby red in color, loads of lovely noticable yeast and lacing.  A thin sticky head with a lovely fruitiness in the aroma.  Well done, bravo!
Once again, just give me a break: RR makes damn good beer.  This is superbly balanced with a candied sweetness, fruit, and yeasty spiciness.  Rich and packed with flavor.  Just pour me another!

750 ml bottle. First glass poured with dark brown with a thin head, second glass poured with a bit more head.The nose had some spice, fruit and a hint of alcohol. Very nicely carbonated, with a nice mouthful. Complex and smooth flavors with a real authentic belgian flavor.Nice bit of sweetness in the finish, but definitely not too sweet. Sort of in between an achel extra and a rochefort 8. From the few RR beers that I have sampled, they really seem to get things right!

Draft at the brewery.  Pitch black, well laced.  This is making me wish Id scheduled a whole day here.  Raisin, licroice, sweetness.  Deliciously balanced.  Sweet, but not too much.  Mildly bitter, but again, not too much.  Tip-toeing along the balance beam the whole way, this comes out exceptionally.  (#3404, 4/10/2008)

Pours a dark cloudy amber with a thick foamy white head.  Aroma is a balnce of maltiness and crisp and dark fruit.  Very quaffable well balanced beer.  Dark fruit flavor is excellently balanced by a healthy amount of malt.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 Bottle from Monument in Concord.  Ive always heard great things about Russian River, and the verdict is now in.  I found salvation in this brew.  An excellent example of the genre.  Great dark-fruit flavor and fullness.  Lots of head.  Great brew.

Bottled from batch 005. I bought this at Ledgers in Berkeley while on a trip to N. Calif. 
Really tight cork, could not twist it off, I needed to use my wine opener! Pours really  nice and the spicey aroma made my nose happy and I knew Im in for a treat. The flavor is huge, malty and just enough dark fruit. Its a very complex beer and Im not sure I can label all that Im tasting but it really lasts for a long time. If this had good availability in my area, I think it would enter my regular rotation! Great beer.

Poured a dark brown with a huge brown head. Smelled of dark fruits and carmel. Tasted of sweet maltiness that hits the palate with a plethora of flavors. We left the bottle out for over and hour and tried a little bit more and the flavor and taste was still superb. Cant wait to try more of these Russian River brews.

Bottled. Thanx omhper.  Hazy, dark ruby colour with thick pale white head. Sweet, malty aroma with spicy, Belgian yeast and loads of aromas: dried fruits, chocolate, fudge, licorice, vanilla. Big flavour sensation here, with licorice, chocolate, dried fruits, caramelized sugars, higher alcohols and of course spicy Belgian yeast. Great, soft mouthfeel, and not as sweet as the aroma suggested.

July 2007 - Pour was deep dark reddish color, clear, with decent head and lacing. Sweet belgian malt flavor with fruits, even a hint of chocolate and lots of spicing. Perhaps a bit overspiced. Rich mouthfeel. A good "on paper" beer, but something about it just left me wanting.

Nice thick layers of dark cherry malt, raisins, oak, apples and some amaretto-like spiciness made this one a nice slow sipping beer. I would love to have the yeast behind this in my primary!  Carbonation wasnt too strong as this one had a drip to it. Sweet tones were there but balanced out just right. It didnt seem overly complex but was refreshing nonetheless.

bottle, batch 006.  pours a hazy reddish mahogany, with a thick lasting eggshell colored head that leaves nice sheets of lacing.  big smell of spicy, bready malts, raisins, figs, black cherries, and oak.  nutty spicy malt taste, with a lot of spice (coriander and a touch of anise, perhaps?), and the fruity esters showing a bit more subtly this time, again with the raisins and cherries, as well as some wood, and maybe a bit of clove and banana.  great finish, with a lingering pleasant bitterness, a touch of sweetness, and a light, radiant warming, in addition to the tinglings that play on your tongue from the spices and the abundant carbonation.  medium bodied, with a creamy but resinous mouthfeel.  a very tasty dark belgian ale.  its not rochefort or st. bernardus (but what is?), and the spice plays a bit too much of a role for my tastes, but still a very enjoyable brew.

Bottled (thanks omhper!). Deep amber colour with mediumsized creamy beige head. Aroma is caramel, fudge, nuts, tropical fruit some licorice and vanilla. Flavour is quite much the same with some spices and dried fruits added. Marvellous brew!

Bottled, thanks, omhper!. Purs out in a hazy ruby brown colour with a rich creamy beige foam. Fresh, yeasty and well-composed aromas of nuts, mild herbs, almonds, minerals, figs, and dates without being overly sweet, just entirely balanced. Yeasty and fruity flavour almonds, spices, dried fruit, burnt sugar and fresh minerals. Very good malt blend here. Full, long, and not nearly cloyingly sweet finish of pepper, grapes, over-riped fruit and mild spices. Great stuff and almost top not notch ale.. Yummy!

Bottled.  Dark ruby, creamy head. Fascinating aroma of lemon, aniseed and licorice. Sweet and densely malty with medium body. Licorice and aniseed are on full display overshadowing grainy roasty flavours and plums. Soft and dangerously drinkable. Salty finish. A beer with lots of character.

On-tap at RR 2/18/08. Pours dark clearish brown with red highlights. Thin white head. Subdued smell of malts and raisins. Tastes of dark overripe fruits, raisins and grapes. A bit of alcohol on the aftertaste. Mouthfeel is somewhat thick and the carbonation is good.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Bottle, batch 010.  Updated rating (score and notes) on 8/24/2011.

Draught at Avery.  Pours hazy brown with a small, frothy, light brown head, diminishing with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, hay, straw), light hops (herbs), average yeast (earth, leaves) with notes of dark melanoidins and fruit (dates, plum, raisin) with vinous notes.  Flavor is malt dominant, light chocolate, dark fruits, and melanoidins.  Medium bodied, gritty texture, lively carbonation, and a dry finish.

Shared w/ exec board.  Pours a dark charred red/orange.  A cream colored head.  Nose of raisins, brown sugar, molasses, and nutty toffee.  A kind of strange sweet and funky taste.  Sourdough with caramel and sweet vanilla.  A lot of malt goodness.  Had a pretty good mouthfeel.  It does make me sad that they dont distribute out this way.

Batch 5. Thanks yet again to Naka for sharing. Sticky sweet caramel in the nose. Dark fruits - figs, cherries, dates. Super sweet aroma. Amazing burgundy with a rocky off-white head. Sweet in the mouth - cherries, prunes, plums, raisins, sugary, and slightly cloying. Freaking superb. Now for my rant. Last night was my first experience with the super hyped Russian River. I love me some good Belgian beer, so Ive been quite eager to give Vinnies work a shot. I was not disappointed. Heres what I like about all their beers I tried - theyre authentic. If I were to taste any of them blind, there would be no way you could convince me it was brewed in the states. So often we see these American "takes" on Belgian styles - some are delicious, many fall short. But very rarely do we see true, authentic Belgian style ales being brewed in America. It breaks my heart, to be perfectly honest. But to know that places like Russian River, Jolly Pumpkin, and Ommegang exist... well, It helps me sleep at night.

750 ml bottle, Batch 5, courtesy of Naka, shared with Exec Board.  Pours brown with red hues, msmall off white head.  Nose is caramel and dark fruits, some funk with a touch of roast.  Taste is funky roast, caramel and raisin, some apple.  Nice dry finish.  This is delicious, beautiful and completely awesome.

Sampled from 750 courtesy of Naka. Sweet aroma, with caramel, alcohol vapor, and woody notes with yeasty goodness and, oddly, cherry. Subtle and fruity. Dark amber, like maple syrup, a bit hazy, with off-white head. Medium-heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Nice notes of caramel, oak and raisin, with mild warming and a bit of tang. Not overly complex, but a nicely balanced strong ale with an authentic Belgian flavor. Smooth, sweet after.

Ah timing is everything.  Stopped by  RR Brewing on my way home from San Francisco and there was Salvation.  While I waited for them to fill my Growler with Pliny the Younger I pleasured my way through a glass of this sublime brew.  In the glass it sat a beautiful ruby that was so dark is looked almost brown, and had a small but attractive head and good lacing.  Nose was of ripe fruit and flowers, Rich mouthfeel.  Flavors are ripe fruit with raisins and plums, and some spices hanging in there at the finish.  Delectable brew.
Batch 5 - Pours a dark mahogany with a tan head. This stuff has a real floral aroma...with a pleasant yeast smell. The flavor is almost wine-like - the spices really work in this one.

Wow was this good .Bottle 005 and it had all the things in a beer i love.It was a dark smooth and malty strong ale with a nice odor and flavor pf bananas and a touch of spice,it was a little sweet but overall it was a great beer.CHEERS!

Bottle. Batch 005. Pours ruby with thick, dense beige head. Aroma freshly-baked dark bread, cherries, orange peel, with subtle herbal hop scent throughout. Intense flavor, thick caramel malts, slightly sweet, nuanced roasted bitter flavors punctuate this. Finish has lingering oily bitterness and the slightest bit of alcohol burn. It coheres like a genuine belgian, well-balanced, excellent palate.

Bottle from the Ross (aka pillow biter). Pours a beautiful deep cherry brown with a tan head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, raisen, and brown sugary malts. This has a solid medium body with a rich earthy texture. Flavor of belgian candi sugar, raisens, and yeast. Mildly sweet and mineral finish. No alcohol flavors detected. Well crafted, but very simple. Nothing overly complex going on, but then again, theres nothing wrong with that.

Bottle from Droop49. Hazy orangeish brown color with plenty of yeast floaties. Faint rotten banana and alcohl in the aroma, not much else. Flavor much the same but with some dubbel/quad qualities. Faint dark fruit, residuel candi sugar, decent caramel/toffee backbone. Overall decent brew, just muddled at times.

Batch 002. Light banana and huge chocolate nose.  Slight acidity in the flavor but not in a sour beer kind of way, more of a dark malt contribution.  Dark rye bread, deep fruit and a lingering wine like finish come together for a great beer.

Batch 5 (also have a few batch 2s that I need to crack, or perhaps save).  This one has a nice cloudy brown color with a nice head.  Aroma is dominated by raisin/plum/fig, dark bread, and a really nice belgian ale yeast smell.  Flavor is nice and bready/yeasty/sweet.  Fruits are noticeable up front, mostly raisin and  plum  with some bready and sugary qualities mid way through.  Also getting some light smokiness and winey/earthy flavors here.  Really nice mouthfeel and a dynamite finish.  Another winner from Russian River.
clear dark orange with thin white head. aroma of powdered sugar & caramel, peat and blue cheese. smooth in the mouth. a blanced sweetness with hints of cabernet, plum & meat smoke. very well crafted.

750 ml corked/caged bottle. Batch 004. Poured a clear brown-orange color. Head was off white and left some lace behind. Aroma was of toasted bread with whiffs of black licorice and a hint of alcohol. Ample carbonation, but a bit thin. Slightly sweet on the tongue with white wine, clove, and subdued brown sugar flavors. Pretty good stuff.

Thanks for sharing general gao. The body was dark brown. The aroma was caramel with some light apples. There was also a little bit of old port. The taste was funky and vinous with a woody finish. I got a little bit of cherry in the beer. This is very interesting.
Dusty, malty aroma.  Reddish brown color.  Woody with roasted malt, cinnamon and bread.  Good.  Thanks to General Gao for this one.

On tap @ RR. Beautiful pour like the color of a prune (in a good way) with a halo of a tan head. Nose is dried fruit, molasses. Flavor is as the aroma, with a touch of candied & brown sugar. Great brew that hides the % very well. Very smooth and easy drinking. Reminds me of an easier drinking Chimay Blue.

Poured deep amber with a thick white head.  Smells of caramel,  fruit,  and banana.  Tastes about the same,  with pickles and pears added.  Strong ABV for 9%,  Id guess this more at 11-12%.  Went down thin but with a good burn.  Fun but odd.

bottle.....pours a bubbly dark brown with decent tan head....nose of sweet dark malt,some biscuity yeast and a little fruit....tastes of caramel, some chocolate that mixed well with some mild tartness that works its way in.  finish is yeasty and funky and a little bit tart.....nice mixture of flavors in a nicely brewed belgian ale.

On tap at Russian River brewery up north. Yummy stuff right here. Deep brown color with nice amber edges and a sticky vanilla head that makes this beer look delicious. Aroma has notes of pear, raisin and banana, followed up by the Belgian yeast that gives it that anticipation of taste. Brown sugar and dark fruits take hold of the flavor, finishing damn smooth on the palate. Alcohol is definitely well-hidden as it claims to be. Thumbs up right here.
My new absolute favorite. Just the right balance of taste and personality. A stand out.

Bottle from Irishboy. Sweet and tart tropical fruit at firs on the nose. Pineapple and banana. Dry and slightly sour yeast. Some brown sugar sweetness. Pours dark brown/copper with a thin white head. Nice, bright tartness on the palate. Some crushed grape sourness. Big yeast component: dry and slightly tart. Creamy on the tongue with lively carbonation.

750 ml enjoyed after an afternoon of painting.  Blue paint still on my fingers (a little darker than I wanted) grab the snifter thats colored a red raisin brown with a thin but dense head.  Aroma is spiced coriander, cherries, chocolate, brown sugar, and banana.  The flavor is complex with cherries, oak, an earthiness, brown sugar, bakers chocolate, peppery and decently bitter from the chocolate.  Complex and unfolding.  Very nicely done.

Bottle 750 ml 
Appearance :Ruby-brown , black sparkle with tanned creamy head.3+. Nose :Fresh , aromatic zesty hops , grainy wheat , hint of rye. Gentle fruity overtone 8-Flavour/Palate : Chewy, woody character with light oak like touch . Softer grainy below went together with cherry fruity finish. Wheat sublimity. Soft warming yet growing with time alcohol note. Pleasant strong ale.

Dark brown in colour, lingering medium sized tan coloured head, good lacing.  The aroma is of dark fruits, candied sugar, yeast, must, rich, very light alcohol.  The flavour is malty, some chocolate, lots of earth, good sweetness, again some very light alcohol, lots of sweet dark fruits.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long and sweet.  Very good, quite creamy.  Lots of chocolate in this one.
750ml bottle shared by <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>mds, thanks Mike.
Opened on October 19, 2007.
Batch 004.

Pours a dark ruby brown with a nice espresso like frothy head.  Smell is wonderful dark fruits and some belgian yeast.  Taste is more, plump, juicy dark fruits.  The label dictates banana, but Im getting some juicy plums, grapes, and possibly even blackberries.  This is a real gem.  Creamy with the perfect amount of carbonation.  This is a winner.

The pour is dark brown, oak shaded, and very murky; foam is nicely lasting.  Aroma is full, layered, and long.  Initial sensation is of orange marmalade and cocoa, with alcohol and aluminum hollowing it out.  Warms into raisins, cinnamon, and caramelized, salted nuts.  Finishing impact of sugar and licorice.  Flavor lends itself mostly toward fruit and general darkness, raisins, apple and pear being most prevalent.  Thick chocolate mousse in the middle that has a rough metallic glint     .  Distantly spicy, hot, but smooth.  It projects a certain aged quality in sherry and alcoholic wetness, bolstered with plenty of doughy, dense yeast character.  Full and lightly prickly in the mouth.   Dirty bakers chocolate and a cooling wave of creme de menthe in a drying finish.  Lovely.

Bottle.  Nice weak coffee colored pour witha dense head.  Subdued aroma - caramel, toffee, malt, burnt popcorn, coffee.  Strong caramel and toffee malt in the flavor, slightly smoky finish, great body.  Nice beer.

Thanks to MikeTD. Murky dark brown pour, medium white head. Aroma is nutty and perfumy. Flavor is big caramel sweetness, very sweet, candy sugar, brown sugar, nutty and toffee. Floral aftertaste. Lots of floral and caramel the whole time with a hint of chocolate. A touch of banana and coffee as it warms.

Batch 002. Notes from 1/2007. 

Pours a clear dark ruby brown with a tan head. Massive lacing. Nose is slightly sweet with a touch of yeast influence. Also heavy amounts of caramel as well. Flavor is tart and tangy. There is a pungent sweet flavor mixed with a slight citric/fruity one. Caramel tones very present. On the end you get an almost bitter edge which seems odd to me off this style. Feel is decent. Not a ton of carbonation and bubble over your tongue, but it is thick with character from ingredients. It is drinkable, yes. In a blind taste test, I doubt anyone would be able to tell that this one came from the U.S. (and not Belgium). However, I feel as if it lacks a level of maturity and oomph that would ever send me back to drinking it again. In the back of my mind, I do wonder if it needed some more age on it.
